 1 PAKISTAN NATIONAL DRAINAGE PROGRAM (NDP) PROJECT 1. THE CRISIS IN IRRIGATED AGRICULTURE A. THE INDUS BASIN IRRIGATION SYSTEM 1.1 Overall Economic Performance: Pakistan's economy has grown rapidly in the last decade. Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth averaged 5.1% annually from 1986 to 1996. Strong agricultural performance (annual growth: 4.1% from 1986 to 1996; 5.3% in 1996; 6.6% in 1995) and an enterprising private sector have been the main factors in Pakistan's growth record. Pakistan is however still a relatively poor country with per capita income of $490 in 1996. The Borrower's primary objectives in the medium- term are to increase per-capita income and to alleviate poverty. Major challenges are improving social services and improving management of natural resources and the environment inter alia by: (i) redefning the roles of the public and private sectors to get the public sector out of tasks which can be more efficiently performed by the private sector; (ii) restructuring public expenditures and key public sector institutions to ensure that the restructured public sector is able to carry out its legitimate role in an efficient and cost- effective manner; and (iii) building the capacities of key public sector institutions to equip them for newly defined roles. 1.2 Role of Agriculture: Agriculture accounts for more than 25 percent of GDP, more than 50 percent of employment, and (directly or indirectly) 70 percent of export revenues. It has a central role in alleviating poverty, given the concentration of the poor in rural areas; and in protecting the environment, given that agriculture is the primary user of natural resources. Agriculture contributes significantly to all other sectors and is the main engine of growth for the economy. Pakistan's agriculture depends heavily on irrigation, which covers 79 percent of the total cropped area of 20.8 million hectares (51 million acres). Irrigated agriculture in turn is by far the dominant user of available water supply, accounting for 98 percent of direct flows and the bulk of re-flows. 1.3 The Indus Basin Irrigation System (IBIS): The irrigation system of Pakistan is the largest integrated irrigation network in the world. The system is fed by the waters of the Indus River and its tributaries. Since 1947, Pakistan implemented the Indus Basin Replacement Works Project (IBRWP) with the Bank's help as the lead donor. Under the IBRWP, 39.54 million acres were brought under irrigation. The salient features of the system are three major storage reservoirs, namely Tarbela and Chashma on River Indus, and Mangla on River Jhelum; 19 barrages; 12 inter-river link canals; 43 independent irrigation canal commands; and over 107,000 watercourses; which are complemented with a surface drainage system comparable in size. The length of canals totals 61,000 kms, and in addition watercourses, farm channels, and field ditches cover another 1.6 million kms. Typical watercourse commands range from 80 to 320 hectares. The flows to the Indus are from Himalayan glacier and snow melt, as well as from rainfall outside the Indus Plain. Diversion of river waters into offtaking canals is made through barrages which are gated diversion weirs. The main canals in turn deliver water to branch canals, distributaries, and minors. The watercourses get their share of water through outlets in the irrigation channels. Distribution of water from a watercourse is effected through a time-share (rotation system) which is locally referred to as "warabandi" under which each farm gets water for a specified period. The time-share or "warn" is proportionate to the farm area owned by a farmer under a command of the watercourse. The system draws an average of 106 Million Acre Feet (MAF) of surface water each year for irrigation, supplemented by an annual groundwater pumpage of some 43 MAF. The average depth of water available at the farm level is 3.07 feet per acre. Approximately 3 million individual farms with an average size of about 12 acres benefit from this system. Average inflows and water use are summarized below:
 2 AVERAGE INFLOWS AND WATER USE IN THE INDUS BASIN Billion cubic meters Inflows into the system from rivers and tributaries 181.37 (100 percent) Diversions to canals 131.16 ( 72 percent) Outflow to the sea 3,9.58 ( 22 percent) System losses 10.63 ( 6 percent) 1.4 Most system losses are due to canal and watercourse seepage, since practically the entire network is unlined. In addition to river diversions, 48 billion cubic meters are pumped annually from groundwater by about 13,500 public and about 400,000 private tubewells. Much of this is recovery from system losses due to seepage in areas underlain by fresh groundwater aquifers. Seepage in areas underlain by saline groundwater aquifers is completely lost to irrigation. Although non-agriculture users extract 5.3 billion cubic meters from the system annually, 80 percent of the extraction returns to the system, albeit with degraded quality. The water requirement for non-agricultural uses is expected to increase from the equivalent of 4% of the surface water diverted for irrigated agriculture at present to about 10-15% within the next 25 years. Most of this water will return to the system, but with a degraded quality. This will in the long term mean unacceptable water quality in the middle and lower reaches of the Indus River and the areas that depend on these reaches for irrigation and domestic water supply. It will also eventually threaten the water supply of Karachi, a city with more than 10 million inhabitants at the outfall of the Indus River, and many of the 25 internationally recognized wetlands in the Indus Basin. B. THE DRAINAGE CRISIS 1.5 The Need for Drainage: An effective and efficient drainage system is essential to sustain environmentally-sound irrigated agriculture. The aquifer on which the IBIS is overlaid averages 3000 feet deep and is completely unified. The Indus Basin has flat topography, porous soils, and semi-arid climate with high evaporation. In such an enviromnent, irrigation without drainage leads inevitably to rising watertables and eventual salinity. Yet even under these circumstances, it is possible, and economically rational, to postpone the provision of drainage while expanding the irrigation network. This is what Pakistan chose to do. 1.6 Results of Drainage Programs: Since 1960, Pakistan has been implementing an ambitious program of Salinity Control and Reclamation Projects (SCARPs: 51 projects to date), the scope of which is summarized in the table below. Much of the drainage effluent is either retained in the IBIS or disposed into the rivers and canals. The drainage solutions which Pakistan has so far applied to the problem have been slow to stem the rising tide of waterlogging and salinity. Furtler, most of the drainage
 3 effluent which is generated is retained or recycled within the basin, as noted above. The consequence of operating a vast, inefficient, and interconnected irrigation system for decades first without drainage, and then later interwoven with an inefficient, inadequate and discontinuous drainage system has been the gradual rising of the watertable and associated salinity. The loss of agricultural land to waterlogging and salinity substantially exceeds the amount of new land brought under irrigation expansion schemes during the same period. 1.8 Magnitude of the Crisis: Waterlogging and salinity are the principal threats to the sustainability of irrigated agriculture in Pakistan: 37.6 percent of the Gross Commanded Area (GCA) is waterlogged', of which 15 percent is severely waterlogged2. 14 percent of the surface is saline3, of which 6 percent is severely saline4. The watertable in the Indus Plain was deeper than 90 feet at the turn of the century. By 1961, it was shallower than 10 feet in 38 percent of the area; by 1981 it was shallower than 10 feet in 45 percent of the area; and by 1989 it was shallower than 5 feet in 15 percent of the area. While the watertable is declining rapidly in most Fresh Groundwater (FGW) areas (the watertable declined from 11.7 feet in 1988 to 23.3 feet in 1995; and is declining by up to 5 feet p.a. in some areas, and 2.1 feet p.a. in Punjab), it is still increasing in some Saline Groundwater (SGW) areas5. Between 1978 and 1989, the area with watertable shallower than 5 feet (pre-Monsoon) increased from 4.8 million acres to 5.9 million acres. The area provided with drainage in which the watertable rose also increased from 0.925 million acres in 1988 to 1.3 million acres in 19916. Salinity is also increasing: in SGW areas, salinity remains at the very high level of 3,900-4,000 parts per million (PPM); and in FGW areas, salinity is estimated to have increased from 900 PPM in 1988 to 940 PPM in 1995. The twin problems of waterlogging and salinity are most severe in Sindh Province (Lower Indus Plain), where more than half of the waterlogged and salinity affected areas are located. There, the watertable is less than 8 feet deep in 37 percent of the areas, 56 percent of the area is moderately saline, and 32.5 percent is severely so. The area requiring drainage in the near future, inclusive of completed and ongoing project areas, is estimated at 19.16 million acres, of which 5.84 million acres are covered under ongoing projects, 2.22 million acres are in areas with completed projects requiring further rehabilitation, and 11.1 million acres have no drainage. 1.9 Impact of Waterlogging and Salinity: The rise of groundwater tables to near the surface in SGW areas, and the consequent soil salinization became, and continue to be, serious environmental problems associated with irrigation in the Indus Basin. The impact of salinity on agricultural productivity is severe: a 25 percent reduction in the production of Pakistan's major crops is attributed by many experts and the Borrower to soil salinity alone7. In Sindh Province where the problem is much more severe, the Borrower estimates that the impact may be closer to 40-60 percent in SGW areas. The critical threshold at which salinity begins to affect the productivity of agricultural land varies by crop. Similarly, the impacts of waterlogging on yields are startling. High groundwater tables inhibit root growth and therefore reduce crop yields. As the depth to watertable decreases to within 5 feet, yields of all major crops begin to decline rapidly. In addition, there are serious environmental and poverty impacts associated with waterlogging and salinity. 1.10 The Current Disposal Strategy: 24 million of the 33 million tons of salt which are brought into the basin annually are retained and recycled within it: (i) 2.2 million tons are stored in evaporation ponds in Cholistan Desert; (ii) 2.6 million tons are stored in Pakistan's largest inland freshwater lakes (Manchar and Hammal) on the Right Bank Indus; (iii) 0.7 million tons are trapped in the Peshawar Valley; and (iv) 18.5 million tons are stored in the aquifer through direct seepage from canals, watercourses, and drains. The rest is disposed into the Arabian Sea via the Lower Indus River itself. This means that salinity levels increase rapidly as extraction of irrigation supplies increases in the Lower Indus. But in addition to distributing river supplied salt, additional salts are mobilized directly onto the surface (and retained) in FGW areas due to tubewell irrigation. 1.11 Drainage Options for Pakistan: Pakistan has three basic options for dealing with its drainage problem. The first option is to dispose the drainage effluent outside the IBIS. The second option is to minimize the drainage effluent by changing the chemistry of drain water, either through dilution and re- use, or through concentration and separation of dissolved salts for subsequent disposal. The third option is to prevent or reduce the volume of drainable surplus through source control. The options are not mutually exclusive. Each of these options must meet the criteria of completeness (the extent to which they can be implemented alone or they rely on other options), effectiveness (the extent to which they solve the drainage problem), efficiency (the extent to which an option is cost-effective), and acceptability (the extent to which an option is acceptable for whatever reasons). 1.12 Conclusion: There is now a widespread consensus between Pakistan and its principal donors that the lack of an effective drainage system for the IBIS is by far the principal threat to the sustainability of agriculture in the Indus Basin, and that it demands urgent solutions. Not only must the drainable surplus be reduced dramatically and permanently at source, but internal drainage must be more adequate, and the IBIS must be provided with a drainage outlet to the Arabian Sea; hence the urgency of constructing the National Surface Drainage System (NSDS). The NSDS is intended to link the Spinal Drain of the Left Bank Outfall Drain (LBOD) to the upper reaches of the Indus Basin in Punjab through a trunk drain, and possibly to the Main Nara Valley Drain (MNVD) on the Right Bank of the River Indus. 1.13 Origins of the Crisis: The principal causes of waterlogging and salinity are irrigation without drainage, over-irrigation, and low delivery efficiency of the irrigation (35 to 40 percent from canal head to root zone) and drainage system. These are in turn rooted in the lack of an appropriate National Water Policy. The semiarid climatic conditions prevailing in Pakistan also lead to accumulation of salts in the root zone. In addition, irrigation supplies add more than 1.2 metric tons of salt per hectare per year to the root zone. Groundwater pumpage, which is unregulated, further aggravates the situation by mobilizing salts dissolved in the groundwater aquifer, if the effluent cannot be safely disposed. 1.14 Policy and Institutional Issues8: The irrigation and drainage system suffers from a number of fundamental problems, notably: (i) unsatisfactory planning and programming of public expenditure on drainage; (ii) implementation delays; (iii) unsatisfactory planning, funding and execution of operation and maintenance (O&M); (iv) deteriorating capabilities of key institutions; (v) lack of public participation; (vi) inadequate investment in drainage; (vii) poor monitoring of drainage projects and infrastructure, and (viii) inadequate investmnent in drainage research, and lack of application of research results to policy and planning. O&M of drainage is inadequately financed. Between FY90 and FY92, Provinces allocated an average of 26 percent less than was required for O&M each year. This translates to almost nil for non- wage expenditures, although O&M for off-farm and sub-surface drainage is largely mechanical. 8 A detailed description of the background of the irrigation and drainage sector, ithe major problems, their origins, diagnosis, and the new sector strategy are outlined in Report No. 11884-PAK: Pakistan Irrigation. and Drainage: Issues and Options; The World Bank, March 25, 1994.
 5 Moreover, cost recovery of O&M is grossly inadequate. Many users and polluters of drains do not even pay for the use of drainage infrastructure. For example, urban centers and industries dispose of municipal waste and toxic effluents in canals and drains without payment or regulation. Meanwhile, the capacity (effectiveness) and efficiency of key drainage institutions has deteriorated significantly over the years. Drainage Circles are reported to be over-staffed by as much as 50 percent in some Provinces. Capacity utilization of drainage O&M machinery varies between 30 and 50 percent. The poor state of drainage O&M is reflected in the periodic need for rehabilitation at roughly every five year intervals. 1.15 Financial Sustainability: After long delays, Abiana (water charges) were increased by 25 percent in the North-West Frontier Province (NWFP), Punjab, and Sindh in 1993. Increases in Abiana ranging between 10 percent to 25 percent were introduced in 1994, 1995 and again in 1996. Punjab is actively disinvesting public tubewells in FGW areas under the ongoing SCARP Transition II Project (Cr. 2257- PAK). This process will be extended to include all FGW tubewells in Sindh and NWFP under the proposed NDP project; and in Punjab under the Punjab Private Sector Groundwater Development Project (Cr. 2901-PAK). This disinvestment is expected to result in a substantial reduction in the overall O&M cost. However, financial sustainability remains an elusive goal for the irrigation and drainage sector in Pakistan. The gap between O&M expenditures and recoveries alone in Punjab was 62% in 1994-95 and increased to 74% in 1995-96; and in Sindh was 89% in 1994-95 and 88% in 1995-96. C. COUNTRY AND SECTOR ASSISTANCE STRATEGY 1.16 Country Assistance Strategy(CAS)9: The core of International Development Association's (IDA's) CAS is to help Pakistan to reduce poverty through investing in people, raising productivity, and promoting economic growth. The three main development challenges to achieve this are: (i) expanding access to improved basic social services including education, health, and rural water supply; and slowing population growth; (ii) supporting fiscal adjustment to maintain macroeconomic stability, and creating fiscal space for development lending; and (iii) nurturing a more competitive environment for private investment. In line with this, IDA's agriculture strategy is to limit the role of public sector, shift management responsibility to the private sector, help remove policy distortions in factor and output markets, improve the efficiency of public expenditures, strengthen institutions and build local capacity, and assist natural resource management and environmental protection. This is also reflected in IDA's strategy for irrigation and drainage which aims to redefine the roles of the public and private sectors by promoting fundamental shifts towards more decentralized and participatory irrigation management systems. The proposed project is in line with this strategy especially since it would initiate and promote major institutional reforms in the irrigation and drainage sector, and address the critical issue of waterlogging and salinity (among the major environmental problems in Pakistan). A key element embedded in every aspect of the CAS is to help Pakistan address the core issue of governance. The CAS also calls for working with the Government to involve communities, the private sector and Pakistan Non-Government Organizations (NGO) more fully in all Bank Group services and in the Government's programs. These are reflected in the design of all components of the project. The project would address the issue of governance through decentralization, promoting more operational and financial transparency, and involving communities substantially in the design, implementation and O&M of projects. 1.17 The Global and Domestic Sector Context: Recent advances in technologies which are readily transferable to Pakistan (including telecommunications, satellite imaging, Geographical Information Systems (GIS), canal lining, and computers) now make investments in modern communications, control, monitoring, and management for irrigation and drainage in Pakistan not only feasible, but also highly attractive financially. The opportunities for achieving high growth rates in Pakistan's irrigated agriculture sector, with very substantial beneficial impacts for the economy, rural poverty, and the environment, are 9 Report No. 15115-PAK: Country Assistance Strategy of the World Bank Group for the Islamic Republic of Pakistan, The World Bank, November 22, 1995; and Board Paper R97-47 IDA/R97-28: Pakistan - Country Assistance Strategy - Progress Report, The World Bank, March 20, 1997.
 6 indeed unprecedented. Paradoxically, the ever expanding gap between the actual and potential technical and economic performance in the sector are wider now than ever before, and is itself a measure of the potential. To harness the enormous potential and opportunities for growth and inivestment requires that Pakistan implement major reforms which will attract donor investment to the sector in the short run, and private investment in the long run. These reforms should have the overall effect of granting farners, domestic and foreign investors, and indeed the public investment program, adequate retums to their investment. This enviromnent is lacking today in Pakistan; and its establishment in the irrigated sector of Pakistan is the over-riding long-term challenge for the Borrower, its Provinces, and IDA. The reformn agenda required to establish this environment includes: (i) encouragement of private domestic and foreign investment; (ii) establishment of reliable and enforceable contracts for delivery of irrigation and drainage services; (iii) establishment of marketable water property rights; and (iv) establishment of a market economy for irrigation and drainage. 1.18 Formulation of a New Sector Strategy: The fundamental ailments of the irrigation and drainage system outlined earlier, for the most part, defied all remedial efforts. An entire range of indicators confirmed the failure of the past strategy in addressing the under-lying causes of the ills of the IBIS: the portfolio under implementation was not closely tied to a coherent strategy or was marginal, and performed badly; Completion Reports by Operations Evaluation Department (OED) decried the lack of sustainability; the Borrower either sidestepped or only half-heatedly implemented difficult policy and institutional refonms; and the performance and environmental indicators for the IBIS continued their deterioration. Clearly, something had to change; a completely new approach was required. Tlerefore, in 1992, IDA stopped all new lending to the sector pending the formulation and agreement with the Borrower on a new strategy which represented a marked departure from previous strategies, in the sense that it addressed the underlying causes of problems, rather than manifest symptoms. As part of the new aggressive change of direction and strategy, the Borrower and IDA agreed to close eight projects between FY92 and FY94 and restructured all the rest. The new strategy was formulated and agreed with the Bonrower in 1994. 1.19 The New Strategy: A new strategy for water resources development in Pakistan was formulated and agreed between the Borrower and IDA"0. It takes a comprehensive approach to River Basin Management (RBM); seeks to enhance the knowledge base to adopt sound technical solutions to drainage; and seeks to reduce fiscal dependency especially for on-farm drainage. The strategy consists of the following interlinked parts": (i) restructuring the Provincial Irrigation Departments (PIDs) to form Public Utilities (PUs) around canal commands; (ii) actively promoting formation and development of Farmer Organizations (FOs); (iii) strengthening federal agencies, notably the Water and Power Development Authority's (WAPDA's) Water Wing, to better implement their federal responsibilities; and (iv) formalizing water mnarkets and individual water property rights"2. The Borrower and IDA recognize that the strategy would only be feasible if there is strong political commitment and the will to implement real/genuine reform in the sector; under a properly defined division of roles between the public sector, community groups, and the private sector, and within the public sector among the Federal, Provincial, and local governments; and that it needs to be supported by a decentralized, efficient and participatory institutional apparatus for planning, regulation, construction, financing, management and O&M'3. 10 The new sector strategy and its rationale is detailed in Report No. 11884-PAK: Pakistan Irrigation and Drainage: Issues and Options; The World Bank, March 25, 1994. 11 See page 44 para 6.1 of the report cited above. 12 Trading of water would also require irrigation canal systems which could allow some flexibility in distributing water; and would evolve over the medium and long-term. THE BORROWER'S OBJECTIVES AND POLICIES 1.20 The Borrower's Priorities and Objectives: Regarding drainage, the Borrower's short-term objectives and priorities articulated in the Eighth Five-Year Plan (FY93/94-97/98) are to accelerate the pace of implementation of ongoing projects, protect borderline waterlogged areas through preventive measures, limit public sector investment in subsurface drainage to SGW areas, and strengthen the linkages between drainage research and development. Other short-term objectives and priorities held in common with the irrigation subsector are to increase the role of the private sector in development and maintenance of water sector infrastructure, pilot-test the concept of autonomous organizations for O&M, and intensify post-completion monitoring and evaluation (M&E). In the long term, the Borrower's priorities for drainage include measures to: (i) reduce the drainable surplus through improved water management, reducing or intercepting seepage at source, and biological drainage"4; and (ii) exploit the residual potential of adversely affected resources, by such means as saline agriculture. These objectives reflect the recommendations of the National Conservation Strategy (NCS) adopted by the Borrower in 1992". To control waterlogging and salinity, the strategy advocates an integrated drainage approach, i.e., a combination of, among other things, intensive cropping and tree planting, promotion of salt-tolerant crops and cropping systems, provision of gypsum for salt-affected areas (gypsum is a soil amendment that facilitates the reclamation of certain salt-affected soils), installation of tubewells, construction of surface drains by farmers, and provision of subsurface drainage for selected areas. The NCS also highlights the urgency of implementing a Wetlands Management Plan. 1.21 The Policy Framework and Drainage Sector Environmental Assessment (DSEA)"6: The Borrower and IDA commissioned the DSEA in response to the perceived deterioration of the drainage and environmental status of the IBIS. The DSEA was financed by a grant from the United Nations Development Program's (UNDP) Umbrella Trust Fund, managed by the Bank, and was completed and published in June 1993. It makes strategy recommendations for the medium term that have been adopted by the Borrower as its strategy. DSEA's strategy is based on the following principles: (i) no project that mobilizes salts from deep groundwater aquifers should be undertaken unless such salts can be safely disposed of in the sea; (ii) additional irrigation water, if available, should not be supplied to areas where this could exacerbate the need for drainage; (iii) the Government should not provide structural drainage interventions that can reasonably be carried out by the private sector; (iv) the Government should confine its subsurface drainage interventions to SGW areas where there is an environmentally acceptable solution for the disposal of drainage effluent; (v) the Government should concentrate its surface drainage interventions in areas where it is justified by the risk of storm water damage or the irrigation process, or where it is linked to private sector drainage or subsurface drainage in SGW areas; and (vi) the Government should give special attention to beneficiary participation in structural and non-structural interventions. 1.22 Implementation: The Borrower is implementing most recommendations of the DSEA by: (i) continuing the ongoing program to phase out government tubewells in FGW areas; (ii) replacing the existing SCARP Tubewells (STWs) in SGW areas with tile drains wherever possible, with beneficiaries assuming responsibility for O&M; (iii) installing tile drains where possible for new drainage development in SGW areas. However, the facilities would be provided only where there are safe options for disposal of the effluent, and only where the beneficiaries agree to be involved in the construction and O&M of the outlets to watercourses are constructed and maintained by PIDs. By the completion date of the program, the Borrower expects to provide the necessary drainage facilities for the entire Indus Basin. 1.24 The National Surface Drainage System (NSDS): The planners of Pakistan's IBIS and its principal donors led by IDA always knew that ultimately, the Indus Basin Irrigation System would require an outlet to the sea. The consultants who carried out the DSEA were required inter alia to evaluate various disposal options to deal with this alarming problem of salinity i.e., other than constructing the outlet to the sea; they concluded that it was neither avoidable nor postponable. Sustainability can only be achieved in the long run by building a NSDS. Given the long lead time required for detailed planning, feasibility studies, and inter-provincial agreement on cost sharing and transportation of saline effluent from the Upper Bank (and possibly Right Bank) Indus to the sea via Sindh Province, work on the NSDS is probably already overdue. 1.25 Institutional Reforms: Within the framework of this project, a package of major reforms which implement all significant aspects of the strategy has been agreed. Most of these reforms are reflected in the Borrower's Sector Development Policy Letters submitted to IDA, dated August 21, 1995 and October 3, 1995. The reforms consist primarily of decentralization and management transfer of the irrigation and drainage system from PIDs to a multi-tier system of autonomous institutions with clearly defined roles and responsibilities within the system; and with a firm commitment to phase out subsidies for O&M in seven to ten years. The hierarchy of institutions and their roles and responsibilities are sumsmarized below: (i) the role of WAPDA's Water Wing would eventually be limited to inter-Provincial functions; (ii) PIDs would be converted into autonomous Provincial Irrigation and Drainage Authorities (PIDAs), with responsibility for the intra-Provincial aspects of the system from barrages to canal headworks, and from main drains that cross canal commands and major drainage basins to inter-Provincial drains operated and maintained by WAPDA; (iii) self-accounting Area Water Boards (AWBs), initially set up as pilots, would be established around selected canal commands to take over and manage the irrigation and drainage system from canal headworks to distributaries/minors operated by FOs, and from the branch drains operated by FOs to main drains operated by PIDAs; and (iv) FOs owned and controlled by farmers would also be encouraged through a series of pilots in each AWB to take over and manage the irrigation and drainage system below the distributaries/minors and subdrains feeding into branch drains operated by AWBs. Initially, the existing FO pilots would be expanded gradually and modified to incorporate the lessons of experience or research. The number would be expanded more rapidly on the basis of one or more successful models that would emerge from the pilots. The legal framework for the institutional reforms has been established with the enactment of the PIDA Acts in all Provinces. The Borrower also intends to implement other important reforms. It intends to reorient the functions and organization of WAPDA's Water Wing towards coordinated management and regulation of the Indus Basin; and streamline W'APDA's organization, internal policies and procedures to increase its overall efficiency. The Chairman of WAPDA outlined these institutional reforms in a letter to IDA dated July 31, 1995. 1.26 Pilot Projects: Under LBOD, a pilot-oriented feasibility study for an AWB on Nara Canal Command is being carried out, with funding from IDA's Institutional Development Fund (Grant No. 28879); and pilots of wholesale (distributary level) FOs are underway in Nawabshah, Sanghar, and

Under On-Farm Water Management III (Ln/Cr. 2245/3327-PAK), three pilots of minor/distributary level FOs are underway (two on minors in NWFP, and one on a distributary in Punjab). Under SCARP Transition II (Cr. 2257-PAK), there has been overwhelmingly positive response from farmers, and ownership from Provinces, to the new approach of using Social Organizers to help farmers establish FOs (around FGW tubewells transferred to farmers), which was introduced after the Mid-term Review (MTR) in 1994. Since then, over 500 village- level FOs have been established in Punjab and 70 in Sindh around FGW tubewells which are being "transitioned" (transferred) from PIDs to fanners, and about 100 more are planned. Building on this beginning, over 6,300 such village-level FOs are due to be established under the proposed Punjab Private Sector Groundwater Development Project. Under the recently approved Balochistan Community Irrigation and Agriculture Project (Cr. 2780-PAK), between 45-50 FOs will be established around community irrigation facilities. The village-level FOs will later be consolidated at the minor/distributary levels under future projects, to benefit from economies of scale. E. EXTERNAL ASSISTANCE TO THE SECTOR 1.27 The Indus Basin Project: The Bank has a long history of collaboration and partnership with Pakistan in irrigation and drainage development ever since Pakistan's independence in 1947. It remains the principal donor to the sector. In 1960, the Bank helped negotiate the Indus Water Treaty between Pakistan and India, with Pakistan acquiring rights to the Indus, Jhelum, and Chenab rivers. Shortly thereafter, the Bank helped Pakistan establish the Indus Basin Development Fund, which financed the Indus Basin Replacement Works Project (IBRWP). The IBRWP was completed to quality, under budget and on schedule (within 10 years). IBRWP helped Pakistan build the world's largest contiguous surface irrigation system. The IBRWP was instrumental in the creation and strengthening of the main institutions currently dominating the water sector in Pakistan, notably WAPDA. In 1958, the Bank helped the Borrower formulate the SCARPs program. 1.28 Planning Studies: In 1973, the Bank assisted Pakistan to formulate the Revised Action Plan, which was the perspective plan for the sector's development in the 1970s. The physical targets of the SCARPs and the Revised Action Plan programs have largely been achieved albeit behind schedule. In 1990, the Bank was again instrumental in the formulation of the Water Sector Investment Planning Study (WSIPS), which served as a perspective plan for the Eighth Five Year Plan (1993-1998) that is currently under implementation. The DSEA was the most recent sector-wide master planning study to be formulated with the Bank's assistance. It will likely serve as the perspective plan for the Ninth Five Year Plan (1998- 2003). 1.29 External Assistance to the Sector: Since 1990, the World Bank, the Asian Development Bank (ADB), Japan, and Germany have been the major sources of external assistance in the water sector in Pakistan. Others who have provided assistance include Canada, France, the Netherlands, Sweden, Switzerland, United Kingdom, European Union, the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD), and UNDP. The Bank has worked closely with the other external agencies in overcoming many of the constraints affecting project implementation and operational performance identified earlier. Since 1993, IDA has been collaborating very closely with other donors on the restructuring and supervision turnaround of the $880 million LBOD (Cr. 1532-PAK); and actively assisting the Borrower in strengthening public sector expenditure programming through the introduction of a three-year rolling Public Sector Development Program (PSDP) for federally funded projects. This has already assisted in accelerating the implementation of water sector projects by enhancing budget allocations and protecting these projects against across-the-board budget cuts. The 1995/96 to 1997/98 PSDP provided a budget of Rs 12.9 billion for irrigation and drainage projects for FY1995/96.  10 involvement in the water sector as important in protecting and enhancing the large investments that have already been made, ensuring that their intended benefits are realized and improving the effective utilization of the Indus river water resources. 1.30 The Lessons of Development Assistance Experience: The lessons of experience, reflected frequently in reports published by IDA's OED on similar Bank/IDA-financed projects in Pakistan, Mexico, Egypt, Indonesia, lndia, and Philippines, and from ongoing implementation of the LBOD Project (Cr. 1 532-PAK) are pertinent to the proposed project. They are: (i) irrigation development should be linked to a proper drainage strategy and investment program; (ii) a long-term solution for disposal of drainage effluent is essential for drainage; (iii) program or policy-based lending is preferred to project-based lending for promoting reform and reducing the backlog/overhang of the portfolio of on-going projects; (iv) Government/donor commitment to too many discrete projects can exacerbate the problem of over- commitment of resources; (v) a strong O&M program with reliable funding and cost recovery should be instituted during implementation and sustained after completion; (vi) capabilities of key institutions to implement projects in a timely fashion should be developed; (vii) farmer's involvement in design, implementation, and O&M is essential for sustainability. The most effective way to achieve their participation is to have beneficiaries bear and finance part of the construction costs, if necessary through credit. Beneficiaries' assumption of part of the cost of the irrigation infrastructure, beginning at the outset of the project, increases their commitment to use the infrastructure effectively, and to recover the money invested in it; (viii) the only effective mechanism to increase cost recovery is to turn over parts of the system to farmers; (jx) monitoring water use in irrigation projects is essential for the good management of this scarce resource. Flow meters, a relatively low-cost item, should be provided as part of future projects; (x) extension services should educate farmers about the importance of the meters and irrigation scheduling to optimize crop production. In larger surface water schemes, measuring devices should be provided as a matter of course at all distribution structures, including even the smallest farm outlets (as small as 50 hectares); (xi) beneficiaries organized in users' associations have demonstrated their responsiveness for O&M of infrastructure transferred to them by Government; and (xii) lack of timely preparation of feasibility studies and engineering designs has been a major constraint to the implementation of time-slice projects. The design of the NDP project reflects the lessons of experience enumerated above. 1.31 Lessons from Research: The lessons from research on water rights in other countries are also of interest"8: (i) there are very substantial welfare and income gains from permitting trade in water, at whatever level; (ii) water rights should be separated from land; (iii) water rights should be allocated based on historical usage, and surplus amounts to usage should be auctioned off; (iv) transaction costs for trading in water are very low, and the availability of adjustable gates is helpful to facilitate such trading; (v) environmental regulations need to be enforced; (vi) the Government has a role to play in resolving the conflicts that could arise; and (vii) public subsidies for O&M of irrigation obstruct water market development. 2. THE PROPOSED PROJECT A. PROJECT OBJECTIVES, FRAMEWORK, AND STRATEGY 2.1 Project Objectives: The goal of the project is to implement the first phase of the Borrower's and Provinces' 25-year NDP which is designed to minimize saline drainable surplus, and facilitate the eventual evacuation of all saline drainable surplus from the Indus Basin to the Arabian Sea, and thereby restore enviromnentally-sound irrigated agriculture in Pakistan. The objectives of the project are to improve the efficiency of the irrigation and drainage system in Pakistan, and ensure its sustaeinability, through: (i) establishing an appropriate policy environment and institutional framework, and strengthening capacity of 18 These results are summarized from Trading Water-Use Rights: What Can We Learn From Chile, by K. William Easter and Robert Hearne, mimeo dated November 28, 1995.
 11 sector institutions (i.e., carrying out the first phase of policy and institutional reforms in the water sector); (ii) improving sector policies and planning; (iii) strengthening the technical foundations of and knowledge base on irrigation and drainage; and (iv) improving the irrigation and drainage infrastructure network. 2.2 Project Framework: The project is the next logical step in a progressive evolution of Pakistan's long-term effort to preserve and develop its most important physical resource -- namely the Indus River Basin -- by strengthening the policy framework and institutional capacity for comprehensive management of the Indus River Basin. The project does this by supporting and mainstreaming participatory approaches to irrigation management which have been pilot-tested in Pakistan for over two decades; promoting collaboration between key agencies of the Borrower and its Provinces inter alia through sharing of information; strengthening real-time water management at basin and sub-basin levels; and stimulating national dialogue on the challenges and opportunities posed to the economy by the progressive deterioration of its key institutions. 2.3 Institutional Appraisal and Sector Analysis: The project has its origins in a multi-year participatory process of analysis, identification, and preparation which was based on recommendations of the Borrower's Water Sector Investment Planning Study (WSIPS, 1990); Eighth Five-Year Plan (1993-98); and DSEA (1993); followed by IDA's sector strategy paper titled "Pakistan Irrigation and Drainage: Issues and Options" (1994)'9. The DSEA, WSIPS, and IDA's sector report contain detailed functional and strategic appraisals of Pakistan's key water sector institutions (i.e. WAPDA and PIDs), which are the principal subjects of reform under NDP. "Steering Committees" with high-level representatives from the Borrower, Provinces, WAPDA, and the PIDs directed and participated in the institutional appraisals (including a series of seminars). In addition, a series of seminars and tours were organized by IDA's Economic Development Institute (EDI) for opinion leaders in all concerned entities to countries which have implemented (or are implementing) identical institutional reforms notably Turkey, Mexico, Chile, United States, Argentina and Dominican Republic. Further appraisal or "assessments" of the institutions was carried out during the preparation and appraisal of the project20. The appraisals confirmed that even though the institutions retain substantial capacities to implement investment programs in the water sector, they suffer from severe systemic deterioration of public sector agencies in Pakistan, especially in the capacity and quality of services they provide. They all are in need of re-engineering to make them adaptable to the sector's evolving requirements for basin-wide environmental management, decentralization, and beneficiary participation. The two river basin master planning studies (WSIPS and DSEA) demonstrated that a Sector Investment Project (SIP) or "program approach" with strong "river basin orientation" would result in a shorter completion period and higher rates of return for investment projects. 2.4 Reducing Saline Drainable Surplus: To reduce the drainable surplus, the project's strategy is to improve water management through non-structural and structural interventions. Non-structural interventions would comprise: (i) institutional reforms to decentralize the irrigation and drainage system; (ii) capacity building of key irrigation and drainage institutions (WAPDA , PIDAs, AWBs, and FOs); and (iii) policies to improve the efficiency of water allocation. Structural interventions would include: (i) modernization of canal system management; (ii) improvement of irrigation systems and watercourses (e.g.: to reduce seepage); and (iii) ensuring proper O&M of canals and drains so that they function as designed. 2.5 Evacuating Saline Drainable Surplus: To evacuate the drainable surplus, the project's strategy is to: (i) use environmentally sustainable methods for disposal of saline drainage effluent (including diverting saline effluent away from freshwater lakes and rivers), and lay the groundwork for construction of a permanent trunk drainage network connected to the sea via LBOD's Spinal Drain which would be known as the NSDS; (ii) improve the planning and programming of irrigation and drainage projects inter 19 Report No. 11884-PAK: Pakistan Irrigation and Drainage: Issues and Options; The World Bank, March 25, 1994. 20 Government of Pakistan: Feasibility Study: National Drainage Program, May 1995.
 12 alia to incorporate and entrench an RBM perspective in all aspects of water resources management by the Borrower, Provinces, WAPDA, PIDAs, AWBs, and eventually FOs, and to provide the critical physical linkages necessary to convert existing drainage systems into operating sub-basin systems; (iii) rehabilitate and modernize drainage systems to remedy the effects of deferred O&M; and (iv) provide research resources to Pakistan's main drainage research institutes to strengthen the technical foundations for drainage, resolve important remaining technical issues in drainage, and develop locally-adapted design criteria. Constructing drainage facilities is a necessary, but not sufficient, condition for achieving sustainable salt balance in the IBIS. All drainage facilities fnanced under the project must also be linked within sub-basins, and then to outfalls which must ultimately connect to the Arabian Sea either through the LBOD Spinal Drain or via the Indus River. "RBM Orientation" will be an important theme in the technical design of physical interventions, particularly those involving rehabilitation or expansion of surface drainage infrastructure. 2.6 Project Design: The project has the following design features which distinguish it from previous investment projects such as those listed above: (a) a sector-wide scope: it covers a wide range of relevant policies, programs and projects within the country's irrigated agriculture sector; (b) a coherent sector policy framework, notably the Borrower's WSIPS, DSEA, and Eighth Five-Year Plan, as well as IDA's Country Assistance Strategy, Water Sector Policy Paper, and sector strategy paper entitled "Pakistan Irrigation and Drainage: Issues and Options." The expenditure program for the project has been and will be assessed according to the criteria outlined in these policy framework documents and Country Portfolio Performance Reviews (CPPRs) through annual reviews of the PSDP which are conducted jointly by the Borrower, Provinces, ADB, Japan's Overseas Economic Cooperation Fund (OECF), and IDA. The Borrower embraced the policy framework outlined in these reports in its Letters of Sector Development Policy to IDA21; (c) strong stakeholder control is embedded in the design, preparation, and selection criteria for Investment Projects and during implementation of Investment Projects; (d) participation of the three main donors for Pakistan's irrigated agriculture sector (IDA, ADB, and C)ECF); (e) a common implementation arrangement for the investment program shared by the three main donors; and (f) a strong anchor in the rolling PSDP for the water sector, as well as a close linkage to the amnual CPPR process. 2.7 Linkage with Future Investments: The Borrower and IDA anticipate that if NDP is successfully implemented, it would be followed by the proposed National Irrigation Prograrn (NIP) which is under preparation22, and by a series of NDPs and other associated investments in the water sector. For that reason, the project includes funds to prepare a pipeline of major drainage projects to be implemented from the second half of this project, and for the preparation of NDP II. On the other hand, if the pace of reforms is slow due to lack of government commitment, implementation constraints, or resistance/lack of commitment by WAPDA, PIDAs or AWBs for real change, the Borrower and IDA have agreed and understand that the incremental financing commitments for irrigation and drainage investments under NDP would be scaled back or canceled altogether after the MTR or 2-3 years; and this factor would be taken into account in determining IDA's financing for additional investments in the water sector notably NIP and the proposed Fourth On-Farm Water Management IV Project. The essential elements of the institutional reforms are: (a) redefining roles and functions; (b) decentralizing roles and responsibilities; (c) streamlining; (d) transferring management responsibility for those functions which should be managed by other (lower tier) entities which will succeed PIDs i.e. PIDAs, AWBs, and FOs, or by the private sector; and (e) capacity building for WAPDA and the new public and private institutions. Training, gender and poverty focus, and public participation are important themes in the capacity building and strategic recirientation programs for all institutions to assist the Borrower and its Provinces to implement institutional reforms. 2.16 Critical Factors for Success: In order to increase the probability of the institutional reform programs being successful and effective, key lessons from global experience in institutional change management have and would be reflected in the design and implementation of the institutional reforms. These include working with the Borrower and other stakeholders for: (a) establishing a shared sense of urgency among the stakeholders; (b) articulating and envisioning the compelling short-, medium-, and long-term vision for the institutions within the framework of evolving competitive environments; (c) establishing effective guiding coalitions with key stakeholders, entities, and strategic partners inside and outside Pakistan; (d) ensuring strong leadership by senior management and officials of the Borrower, Provinces and WAPDA; (e) seeking, consolidating, and using extensively the programs of two-way and multi-dimensional information, education, and communication with agency staff, the media and other stakeholders; (f) rnaintaining full-time teams dedicated to the change effort at WAPDA and Provincial levels; (g) using positive demonstrative effects of early successes; (h) engaging large numbers of staff in the change effort; (i) embedding institutional change in the evolving cultures of the changed institutions; () intensively monitoring the change process including through staff and client surveys; (k) using outside consulting assistance wherever necessary; and (1) maintaining and demonstrating a strategic, dynamic/
 15 flexible, client-centered and pragmatic orientation towards the change process itself, with emphasis on the process variables of change (as contrasted with a blue-print approach). Institutional Reforms for WAPDA's Water Wing (Cost Estimate: $31.4 million) 2.17 Summary: The Chairman of WAPDA outlined the institutional reforms which the Senior Management of WAPDA have envisaged for the Water Wing in a letter to IDA dated July 31, 1995. The sub-component will help WAPDA to implement the program outlined in this letter. It would consist of initiatives to assist WAPDA's Water Wing to implement its institutional program consisting of: (a) strategic and RBM reorientation to focus on inter-Provincial (i.e. federal) roles, mandates, and functions; (b) streamlining to improve capacity utilization, operational efficiency and effectiveness; (c) capacity building, including public participation, financial management, and information systems; and (d) training. The sub-component would provide consulting services to help WAPDA establish effective strategic partnerships with similarly oriented institutions in Pakistan and elsewhere, training for staff and important categories of clients such as contractors, field observation equipment, laboratory equipment, and computer equipment and software, to support the initiatives outlined by WAPDA's Senior Management. WAPDA would prepare, and agree with IDA on, a detailed Action Plan with a schedule for its Institutional Program; and subsequently implement the Action Plan. 2.18 Strategic Reorientation & RBM: The strategic reorientation work program would support reorientation of WAPDA's Water Wing to strengthen its role towards more strategically important and federally oriented responsibilities, in particular those related to integrated development, management and regulation of surface and ground water resources at the river basin level; monitoring of land and water quality and environmental change; and planning, construction and O&M of inter-Provincial irrigation and drainage infrastructure. WAPDA would shift its focus away from construction of infrastructure which can be undertaken by Provincial agencies (i.e., intra-Provincial infrastructure) or which should be the responsibility of the farmers or the private sector (notably on-farm drainage). The aim would be to reorient the functions and organization of WAPDA's Water Wing towards coordinated management and regulation of the Indus Basin (i.e. "RBM Orientation"). The role of WAPDA's Water Wing would gradually be reoriented to inter-Provincial functions; and to undertake any work contracted to it by the Borrower, Provinces, PIDAs, AWBs, and FOs. In addition, the project would assist WAPDA's Water Wing to enter the Information Age in the 21st century by turning it from a construction agency to a "knowledge water resources agency"; establishing more effective mutual dependencies, partnerships and collaborative arrangements with Provincial entities (Environmental Protection Agencies - EPAs, PIDAs, PAD-OFWMs, AWBs and FOs), and national, international, non-governmental, and private sector entities. 2.19 Streamlining: The streamlining work program would support efforts of WAPDA's Senior Management to streamline its organization, intemal processes, and procedures to improve institution's operating efficiency and its capacity to manage the Indus Basin as a unified hydrological entity. This would involve a process of identifying and removing obstacles to the utilization of existing and potential institutional capacity, and streamlining its operations and management. 2.20 Capacity Building: Capacity building is the largest initiative in the sub-component. It would finance initiatives aimed at creating or strengthening institutional capabilities in WAPDA's Water Wing for RBM through specific interventions in aspects of its operations such as environmental management, M&E, public participation, financial management, information systems, procurement and contract administration, planning, and succession planning. The component would also fund training programs which would be formulated in consultation with OECF, ADB, and concerned agencies in Provinces. OECF has proposed that UNDP (Pakistan) would manage, coordinate and supervise the training component financed by OECF. Collaborative arrangements would also be established to ensure synergies between EDI's Participatory Irrigation Management (PIM) Program and the priorities of WAPDA's Academies and Colleges, notably on decentralization and irrigation management transfer. The expected retirement of a substantial number of senior managers in WAPDA poses major challenges, but also presents unique opportunities for renewal and reorientation of the institution. This project component would provide the
 16 resources and framework to help the Borrower and WAPDA address the issue during the pivotal transition phase for WAPDA. Institutional Program for PIDs (Cost Estimate: $26.3 million) 2.21 Summary: This sub-component would include the costs of consultants (including financial and management consultants, social organizers, service contracts with NGOs, and external auditors), vehicles, computer equipment and software, staff training, alternative skills development and redundancy packages, and incremental staff and operating costs to assist in the planning and implementation of the decentralization of PIDs and management transfer of the irrigation and drainage infrastructure process. The sub-component would support the following initiatives: (a) establishment of PIDAs, pilot AWBs and FOs on pilot basis in each Province; (b) transitioning irrigation systems from the PIDAs to AWBs and FOs; and (c) streamlining and cost reduction among the decentralized PIDAs, AWBs, and FOs to enable them to carry out their functions; and (d) capacity building of the PIDAs, AWBs, FOs and PAD-OFWMs. 2.22 The Policy Framework: In August 1995, the Borrower decided in consultation with its Provinces and IDA and ADB that it would implement the strategy/vision agreed with IDA and ADB by adopting institutional arrangements that were appropriate for Pakistan's socio-economic conditions. The strategy and institutional reforms are outlined in the Borrower's Sector Development Policy Letters to IDA. The reforms include a firm commitment and plan to phase out subsidies for O&M in seven to ten years. 2.23 The Institutional Reforms: The Borrower and its Provinces intend to: (i) convert their PIDs into autonomous PIDAs; (ii) transition fmancially self-accounting AWBs on a pilot basis from existing "Circles" of PIDs in selected canal commands; and (iii) promote the formation of FOs on a pilot basis. Pilot FOs owned and controlled by farmers would take over and manage the irrigation and drainage system below the distributaries/minors, sub-drains feeding into branch drains operated by pilot AWBs, tubewells and tile drains. While the Borrower, its Provinces and IDA agree on the direction of reform, the pace at which the decentralization and management transfer process can or should be implemented is as yet unclear. The likely trajectory of institutional reforms in each Province will depend on a number of factors whose evolution is difficult to predict, but include: (i) first and most important, the commitment and political will of the Borrower and its Provinces to exercise leadership in implementing the decentralization and management transfer process; (ii) second, the implementation capacity of each Province and its consultants to implement the decentralization process; (iii) third, the willingness and cooperation of the affected farming population (notably the more influential feudal landlords); and (iv) fourth, the willingness of PIDs (notably their staff) to embrace the reforms. 2.24 Legal Framework and Enabling Legislation: The Canal and Drainage Act of 1873 is the over- riding legal framework for the irrigation and drainage sector. During project preparation, the NDP Feasibility Study Consultants investigated the possibility of implementing the institutional reforms envisaged under the project without enacting new legislation or amending existing legislation, and concluded that at the minimum, amendments would be required. The PIDA Acts provide the legal framework for establishment of PIDAs, AWBs, FOs, and regulation of the decentralized water sector. The PIDA Ordinances were promulgated by all the Provinces in January 1997, in the absence of Provincial Assemblies. Following the general election in February 1997, all the Provincial Assemblies have approved the PIDA Acts, and all provinces have reenacted the PIDA Acts. Assurances were obtained at Negotiations that the Provinces would establish at least one A WB in a canal command in each Province, selected in consultation with IDA, within one year of the establishment of the PIDA. 2.25 Adequacy of the Enabling Legislation: Our review of the PIDA Acts has confirmed earlier indications from dialogue with the Borrower and Provinces, that the Acts are adequate to implement the institutional reforms envisaged under the project. However, there is still scope for improvement in the following areas: (a) providing for more autonomy for PIDAs and AWBs; (b) clearly describing the roles and responsibilities of AWBs, and in case of some Provinces of FOs; (c) describing the organization of the
 17 AWBs; (d) providing for the establishment of a separate or quasi-autonomous agency to regulate and adjudicate the decentralized irrigation and drainage institutions and infrastructure; (e) providing for fuller and faster financial self-sustainability of PIDAs and AWBs (rather than partial self-sustainability - of operation and maintenance costs only - over a 7-10 year time frame provided for in the Acts); and (t) providing for faster financial self-sustainability of Farmer Organizations (rather than 7 years provided for in the Acts). Nevertheless, the PIDA Acts are adequate in their present form. Subsequent refinements and improvements are expected during implementation. The above issues will be addressed during implementation through dialogue, and as the political environment becomes more favorable. The Borrower and the Provinces have agreed that they would annually review the PIDA Acts based on the experience of implementation, and would agree with the NDP donors on any amendments and improvements to the statute. This is reflected in the agreed Action Plan for the project (Annex 7). 2.26 Agreements and Safeguards: The strong commitment of the Borrower to implement the reforms as indicated in the Sector Development Policy Letter and WAPDA's Institutional Program Letter, promulgation of the PIDA Ordinances in all Provinces, their subsequent approval by Provincial Assemblies, and reenactment by the Provinces have provided IDA with satisfactory basis for the financing of the project. There however remains a risk that the Provinces may modify important provisions of the PIDA Acts for whatever reason to the detriment of the project. Sufficient safeguards have been built into the design of the project. The Borrower and IDA have agreed and understand that the incremental financing commitments for irrigation and drainage investments under NDP would be scaled back or canceled altogether after the MTR if the pace of reforms is slow due to lack of government commitment, implementation constraints, or resistance/lack of commitment by WAPDA, PIDAs or AWBs for real change. This factor would be taken into account in determining annual incremental financing commitments to participating agencies (PA) under the project, and in determining IDA's financing for additional investments in the water sector. In addition, only PIDAs, AWBs and FOs which are established and meet the eligibility criteria would be eligible to participate in the project23. The General Conditions (Section 6), Development Credit Agreement (Section 5.01 e which specifies remedies of the Association in the event of repeal or material modification of the PIDA Ordinance), and Project Agreement (Section 2.04 which specifies eligibility criteria for annual incremental fnancing commitments to PIDAs, AWBs and FOs, and the Action Plan for the Project referred to in Section 2.01b) afford the necessary safeguards and remedies to IDA. 2.27 Streamlining and Cost Reduction in Operations of Decentralized Irrigation Institutions: The project would finance the costs of conducting more thorough and participatory institutional assessments; redefining the mandates, and developing business plans; and introducing organizational adjustments, structuring, and realigning levels' and composition of staff of PIDAs, pilot AWBs, and pilot FOs. To help the new entities achieve significant cost reductions and improve their productivity, Provinces would impose hiring freezes on all PIDAs and AWBs, reassign redundant staff to other organizations, and offer them incentives for early retirement. The project would also provide assistance to PIDAs and AWBs to "transition" (i.e. transfer) FGW tubewells, on-farm tile drains, and sub-drains to farmers through FOs. This process is expected to generate significant cost savings. To this end, the project would finance the costs of PIDAs, AWBs, and FOs to conduct "Diagnostic Reviews" and prepare Business or Operational Plans of their irrigation and drainage operations. E. Available funds from the project would not be allocated to WAPDA or Provinces on the basis of pre-determined shares, but on merit based on readiness of the pipeline of Investment Projects and the demonstrated absorptive capacity of WAPDA or Provinces. 3.10 Provision of Funds by Provinces to PIDAs, AWBs and FOs: Provinces would make available IDA funds, together with their own counterpart contributions, to eligible PIDAs, AWBs, and FOs, on a first-come-first-served basis taking into account the demonstrated absorptive capacity of each entity, as a grant and on the terms stipulated in a Participation Agreement between the Provinces and the entity. Agreement was reached at Negotiations that Provinces would enter into Participation Agreements, satisfactory to IDA, with each PIDA, A WB and FO proposing to participate in the Project. Aspects which would be covered in Participation Agreements are given in Annex 3. 3.11 Incremental Financing Commitments: IDA would make incremental fmancing commitments annually for new programs of activities to be commenced in each Fiscal Year based on the "Consolidated NDP Three-Year Rolling Business Plan" (the Business Plan). The Borrower would submit the draft Business Plan for the project to IDA by March 31 of each year, and agree the Plan with IDA by April 30 of each year. The Plan would include procurement, staffing, operations, and fmnancing plans and encompass all components and PAs of the project. Agreement was reached at Negotiations that the Borrower would, not later than April 30 of each Fiscal Year ofproject implementation, or such later date as IDA may agree, beginning Fiscal Year 96-97, furnish to IDA for its approval, proposals for amounts to be allocated out of the proceeds of the Credit for financing any new program of activities to be commenced under the project in the next following Fiscal Year of project implementation. IDA would not approve any proposals or awards of contracts for Investment Projectsfurnished to it unless and until: (a) the Borrower has, with the participation of WAPDA and the Provinces, prepared and furnished to IDA: (i) a consolidated Annual Progress Report (APR) on the carrying out of the programs of activities previously commenced under the Project; (ii) a Three-Year Rolling PSDP for the project for the next three following Fiscal Years ofproject implementation; (iii) a Portfolio Action Plan for the project for the next following Fiscal Year of project implementation; and (iv) a Three-Year Rolling Business Plan for the project, which would also include procurement and disbursement targets, for the next three following Fiscal Years ofproject implementation; and (b) IDA is satisfied with the progress made in the carrying out of: (i) the programs of activities previously commenced under the Project; and (ii) the current Portfolio Action Plan and Three-Year Rolling Business Plan for the Project.

PROCUREMENT 3.12 Procurement Assessment and Management: A formal Country Procurement Assessment (CPA) was completed for Pakistan, and the Country Procurement Assessment Report (CPAR) is expected to be published soon. Work that is nearly complete will result in country-specific Standard Bidding Documents (SBDs) which are agreed between IDA and the Borrower. WAPDA, the key implementing agency for NDP, has been the central partner with IDA in this review process, and (together with the Pakistan Engineering Council, PEC) is helping IDA develop SBDs for Pakistan. Notvithstanding the recently observed deterioration of institutional capacities of WAPDA and PIDs in procurement and contract administration, the Borrower, Provinces, and WAPDA in particular, have extensive and generally satisfactory records of compliance with IDA procurement procedures. Two comprehensive reviews of WAPDA's procurement and contract administration procedures were undertaken by consultants appointed by WAPDA following the recommendations of the MTR and 1993 Joint Review Mission for LBOD, and as part of the Feasibility Study for NDP in 1994. The reviews identified areas of weakness (mostly having to do with delays in decision making) and made recommendations for improvement which are incorporated as part of the Institutional Program for WAPDA, specifically engagement of consultant procurement specialists to overcome institutional shortcomings, and mandatory assignment of NDP Design and Engineering Consultants as the Engineer on all civil works contracts fmanced under the project. 3.13 The Borrower's Procurement Arrangements: Taking these factors into account, the Appraisal Mission concluded that the Borrower, WAPDA, prospective PIDAs, AWBs, and FOs would be capable of handling procurement, supervising contract administration, and engaging and supervising consultants envisaged under NDP with the help of procurement consultants and establishment of an NDP Procurement Unit. WAPDA would also appoint one or more consultants with internationally recognized professional qualifications in procurement administration, from NDP Engineering Design and Supervision Consultants or other consultants, as NDP Procurement Advisers to provide technical assistance and training to staff of WAPDA, PIDAs, AWBs, and FOs on procurement. 3.14 Procurement Elements and Plan: Under the proposed project, IDA will finance civil works for construction (including rehabilitation and improvement of drains, canals, watercourses, and tubewells, and performance-based contracts for O&M of irrigation and drainage infrastructure); equipment and vehicles; and consultant services (including Research Contracts). WAPDA, PIDAs, AWBs and FOs will prepare detailed Three-Year Rolling Procurement Plans as part of their Three-Year Rolling Business Plans. The NDP Coordination Cell in WAPDA will consolidate the procurement plans of PAs, and submit the combined Three-Year Rolling Procurement Plan for IDA's review and approval by March 31, together with the project's Combined Business Plan. Contracts for civil works will be considered only as part of complete Investment Projects and be awarded only after the Investment Project has been approved by IDA. IDA's Guidelines for Procurement under IBRD Loans and IDA Credits would be ifollowed for procurement of all works and goods financed from the Credit. Consultants financed from the Credit would be selected following IDA's Guidelines for Selection and Use of Consultants. PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION A. THE PARTICIPATING AGENCIES (PAS) 4.1 Responsibilities of PAs: The Borrower would have overall responsibility for coordinating and monitoring project implementation. The Sector Planning sub-component would be implemented by the Borrower, WAPDA's Water Wing and Provinces depending on the nature of the studies. The Drainage Research sub-component would be implemented by Research Institutes, under a contract with WAPDA's Water Wing. The Institutional Reforms for WAPDA's Water Wing would be implemented by WAPDA's Water Wing; while that for PIDs would be implemented by Provinces through PIDAs, AWBs, PAD- OFWMs, and FOs. Investment Projects would be carried out by the various PAs which have operational jurisdiction over the Investment Project. FOs would carry out on-farm drainage, and on-farm irrigation upto minor/distributary level, both with assistance from PAD-OFWMs. AWBs would carry out intra- provincial irrigation and drainage (other than on-farm drainage and irrigation) within their respective canal commands. PIDAs would carry out intra-provincial irrigation and drainage (ot]her than on-farm drainage and irrigation) outside canal commands and within canal commands in which AWBs have not been established. WAPDA's Water Wing would carry out inter-provincial irrigation and drainage. WAPDA's Environmental Cell and Provincial EPAs would have the lead role in preparation, review, approval, and implementation of environmental aspects of the project including Environmental Impact Assessments (EIA), Environmental Management Plans (EMP), environmental audits, and Information, Education, and Communication (IEC) campaigns for the activities to be carried out by WAPDA and Provinces respectively. B. ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA AND APPROVAL OF PROGRAMS 4.2 Eligibility Criteria for PAs: The PAs are indicated in para 4.1 above. Additional PAs may be added on terms and conditions satisfactory to IDA. Assurances were obtained at Negotiations that each PA would satisfy the specified eligibility criteria to be eligible for incremental annual financing commitments from the IDA Credit for new programs of activities to be commenced under the Project, and any new contracts to be awarded by it for on-going Investment Projects. The agreed eligibility criteria are detailed in Annex 6. Eligibility criteria for PIDAs, AWBs and FOs inter alia include that they: (i) are established and operated as autonomous entities; (ii) have prepared and agreed with the NDP Coordination Cell a Three Year Rolling Business Plan including demonstrating progress towards financial self- sustainability of O&M costs for PIDAs and AWBs within ten years of establishment, and financial self- sustainability for FOs within seven years of establishment; and (iii) have achieved satisfactory progress in implementation of their Business Plan for the previous Fiscal Year including achieving targets for cost reduction, O&M expenditure and collecting Abiana and cost-sharing (beneficiary contribution) amounts. Eligibility criteria for PAD-OFWMs inter alia include that they have achieved satisfactory progress in implementation of their Business Plan for the previous Fiscal Year including collecting cost-sharing (beneficiary contribution) amounts. Eligibility criteria for WAPDA inter alia include that it has achieved

Members of the FPSC include the Federal Secretaries for Finance, Planning and Development, Economic Affairs; Additional Chief Secretaries (ACS)-Development of Provinces; and the Chairman of WAPDA. The Borrower has established the Federal Irrigation and Drainage Cell (FIDC) in MW&P, which will be the Federal Secretariat for the project with responsibility to the Borrower and cofinanciers for policy and institutional reforms under the project and for the functioning of the FPSC.
