BENEFITS, JUSTIFICATION AND RISKS A. BENEFITS AND POVERTY IMPACTS 5.1 Summary: The project's most significant direct benefit would be to tenant farmers, smallholders, and tail-enders in the form of increased efficiency of service delivery, improved availability of irrigation and drainage supplies, and reduced cost. The project's principal short term benefits will come from the physical drainage and irrigation improvements and better O&M resulting in more effective drainage, which in turn will result in an improved environment and increased output of agricultural produce. This will have a direct and positive impact on poorly drained land that falls within the command of each Investment Project, regardless of the socioeconomic characteristics of farmers cultivating these lands. Estimates indicate that farmers benefiting from the drainage improvements can expect to increase their income by up to 30 percent, depending on the original condition of waterlogging and salinity and on the agro-ecological conditions. The project's principal medium- and long-term benefits (particularly from the institutional reforms in Provinces) will come from improved drainage and irrigation-related policies, improved efficiency of public expenditures on drainage O&M, improved capability in the public sector to plan and implement water sector projects and in the private sector to undertake drainage-related investments, improved and more equitable availability of irrigation supplies and drainage facilities, improved efficiency, and (potentially) lower cost of delivery of irrigation and drainage services as a iresult of decentralization and participation by beneficiaries. These benefits will potentially be far greater than those from the physical investments. All of these will benefit the smallholder farmers and tenants in particular, and environment and the agriculture sector as a whole; and enhance sustainability of the land and water resource base. A detailed analysis of project benefits and costs is given in Annex 9). 5.2 Production Benefits: The project would have two important impacts. Drainage installation would lower the groundwater table and reduce soil salinity, thereby leading to significant improvements in yields. The project also addresses a long-term issue: without the project, future yie-lds would progressively decline from their current levels. Therefore, the project would have two additional benefits: (a) avoidance of further yield (production) losses, which would result if the groundwater and salinity problems were to persist; and (b) productivity increases resulting from reduced waterlogging/salinity problems. The "without" project scenario is one of a continuing trend of substantial losses in agricultural production, and ultimately further environmental deterioration and increased rural poverty for farmers. The increasing levels of salinity and waterlogging would reduce yields to almost zero. Large areas of crop land would completely go out of production in the "without" project scenario. Productivity increase is, by far, the most important of the two benefit subsets. Insofar as improved drainage may have positive effects on agricultural technologies or cultural practices which are not included in the above estimate, the benefits are understated. Based on the identified and projected pipeline of Investment Projects, the project is expected to benefit many farmers directly, and the entire irrigated agriculture sector indirectly, by reclaiming abandoned land, rehabilitating existing lands, and potentially improving drainag;e in about 13.5 million acres. Productivity is estimated to improve over a period of about five years by about 2 percent for the entire IBIS command areas, and by about 20 percent for tail-end farmers. Tail-end farmers would also realize additional benefits from a reduction in costs of production and improved availability of water through the activities of FOs. Specific interventions of the project such as lining watercourses and
 37 rehabilitation of canals would also increase the amount of fresh water that reaches the tail-end of watercourses in SGW areas. 5.3 Positive Poverty Impacts: Areas which are affected by high levels of waterlogging and salinity tend to have the lowest incomes, high unemployment, and lawlessness in Pakistan. Hence waterlogging and salinity problems have a poverty and equity dimension too. They affect the rural poor (especially those at tail-ends of watercourses and minors) and landless tenants most severely. By helping to raise agricultural output, farm incomes, providing additional employment opportunities in those areas, the project will help alleviate rural poverty and improve the socio-economic prerequisites for law and order. The selection criteria for Investment Projects are designed to skew the benefits in favor of tenant farmers, smallholders, and tail-enders. Specifically, Investment Projects would, to the extent possible, be designed to benefit small farmers, women, and poorest one-third of the income strata of the members of the farming community. This would be demonstrated through a Social Assessment for the Investment Project. The institutional reforms, particularly the formation of FOs, are expected to increase the transparency and equity of water allocation and use. 5.4 Other Positive Impacts: The project's interventions would reduce the O&M expenditures for social infrastructure such as roads, power distribution, public housing, etc. The project would also provide appropriate spill-over effects on non-farm growth through backward and forward linkages, including increasing employment opportunities in the non-farm sector Estimates from research findings indicate that every one percent increase in per capita farm growth would provide a 1.5 percent increase in per capita non-farm growth. RISKS AND SENSITIVITY ANALYSIS 5.13 Project Risks: The project is a 'high reward-high risk' venture. The project in general and the institutional reforms in particular if implemented, would provide enormous benefits as outlined earlier. These reforms represent the only solution to ensure the long-term sustainability of the irrigation and drainage system and the agriculture sector of Pakistan. However, the project also has very significant risks. These risks, as well as the risk-mitigation and risk-management factors/strategies53, are discussed below under the following headings: (i) derailment of the institutional reform program; (ii) slow or imperfect formation of FOs; and (iii) sustainability of investments in irrigation and drainage infrastructure. 5.14 Derailment of the Institutional Reform Program: As is inherent in any major reform program, the institutional reforms supported by the project carry very significant risks. The proposed institutional reforms would significantly affect the existing power relationships and alliances in rural Pakistan. While the reforms largely seek 'win-win' situations, the perceived (and in part, real) threat of loss of control over the system, particularly by feudal landlords who are unaccustomed to sharing water and power, and by irrigation bureaucrats with financial ties to these interests, who stand to benefit from the continuation of the institutional status quo, could provoke strong adverse reactions. Large and povverful landlords view the proposed transformation of PIDs into autonomous PIDAs and AWBs, the formation of FOs and the transfer of management responsibilities of the tertiary system to these FOs, and the establishment of water rights as potential threats to their traditional control over the irrigation and drainage system in particular, and the social structure (feudal system) in general. Some sections of the PIDs, which when transformed would be faced with a hard budget constraint, more accountability, financial transparency and scrutiny, and possibly reduced costs and staffng, view the reforms as threats to their power, authority and rent-seeking opportunities. Similarly, the proposed strategic reorientation of WAPDA which seeks to transform WAPDA's role from large-scale construction to knowledge-based RBM, and the progressive transfer of its construction activities in intra-provincial and on-farm infrastructure to PIDAs, AWBs and FOs, is viewed 53 Risk-mitigation factors/measures are factors/measures to reduce the probability of risk; while risk- management strategies are measures which would be taken to minimize loss if the risk materializes.
 41 by some officials as a diminution in WAPDA's role in management of the irrigation and drainage system. There is a risk that these vested interests (who have very significant political and financial clout) would slow, or even stop, reform. The proposed reforms have already provoked strong adverse reactions from these opponents in the form of spreading misinformation, organizing political opposition, and bureaucratic delays and stalling tactics including continuous whittling down of reform proposals at various stages. 5.15 Risk-mitigation: Demonstration of strong political commitment and leadership by the Borrower, Provinces, and WAPDA to follow through with the institutional reforms, especially regarding decentralization and management transfer of the irrigation and drainage system is crucial to mitigating this risk. So far, this has been forthcoming. The ownership for the reforms at the highest levels is strong especially since the institutional reform strategy was formulated by the Borrower based on its assessment of the reforms' likely ownership by the people of Pakistan and chances of success in Pakistan's environment. The reform program was first endorsed at the highest political levels on August 19, 199554; and has been repeatedly re-endorsed at similar levels on several occasions by three successive Governments (Federal and Provincial) since then, sometimes in the face of mounting opposition from organized groups (notably large landholders, feudal landlords, and some officials of PIDs). The Borrower and Provinces engaged in extensive consultations with the various stakeholders (including politicians, organized farmer groups, Chambers of Agriculture, Provincial Departments, etc.) to build consensus and win acceptance of the reform program, including on the PIDA Acts. The political and wide-ranging support for the reform program was most recently demonstrated in the approval of the PIDA Acts by all the four Provincial Assemblies and the reenactment of the PIDA Acts55. The extensive debate on the reform strategy, wide-ranging consultations, and the resulting education about the reforms have lowered the perceived threats of the reforms to some degree. The project's risk mitigation strategy is: (i) to continue to encourage political debate about irrigation policy in Pakistan, and thereby help build both conscious top- level political ownership and widespread support among the various stakeholders for the reform program; (ii) strengthen the constituency for reforms through extensive technical assistance, communication and beneficiary participation programs; and (iii) establish institutional focal points in the Federal Government (e.g.: the FIDC), WAPDA (e.g.: NDP Coordination Cell, and possible Institutional Change Department), and Provinces (e.g.: NDP Cells, transition wings in PIDAs and AWBs, and FOs) and provide technical assistance to create the necessary incentives and mandates, and equip them with resources/capacity to function as agents for institutional change. In spite of these measures, real institutional reform is by no means assured. There is the danger that the PIDAs and AWBs could be captured by corrupt and incompetent officials, and that the PIDAs and AWBs would lack the operational and financial autonomy to function as effective institutions". 5.16 Risk-management Strategy: The project's risk management strategy (in the event that all or part of the risk materializes) is two-fold: (i) IDA would only finance those PAs and Investment Projects which conform to the institutional reform strategy. Specifically, the eligibility criteria for PAs provide for each PIDA, AWB and FO to be eligible for incremental financing commitments only if it is established and operated as an autonomous entity; and the selection criteria for Investment Projects provide for Investment Projects to be financed only if they are carried out by PAs which have operational jurisdiction over the Investment Project; (ii) the Borrower and IDA have agreed and understand that IDA's incremental financing commitments for irrigation and drainage investments under NDP would be scaled back or canceled altogether after the MTR if the pace of reforms is slow due to lack of government commitment, implementation constraints, or resistance/lack of commitment by WAPDA, PIDAs or AWBs for real change. 54 At a meeting involving the President, Prime Minister, the four Provincial Chief Ministers, Cabinet officials, and Secretaries from the Borrower and all the four Provinces. 55 In the absence of Provincial Assemblies, the PIDA Statutes were originally promulgated as Ordinances in all the four Provinces; and reenacted by the Provincial Assemblies after the general elections in February 1997. 56 Although the PIDA Acts have several provisions to ensure autonomy of PIDAs and AWBs.
 42 5.17 Slow or Imperfect Formation and Functioning of FOs: Effective FOs will ultimately be essential for the financial sustainability of the irrigation and drainage system. FOs are crucial not only for assuming responsibilities for O&M of the tertiary system (i.e., on-farm drainage and irrigation upto the minor/distributary level), but more importantly to ensure that that the AWBs and PIDAs are held accountable for service delivery, maintenance of physical structures, and assessment of charges, and to bring user discipline to water distribution. However, there is a risk that formation of FOs may be very slow especially since the proposed FOs are to be established in a highly differentiated environment with respect to land ownership, water rights and economic needs, and with a mixed record from Water Users Associations and farmers' cooperatives. Feudal landlords could use their existing social power-hold to frustrate social mobilization efforts and prevent formation of FOs. There is also a risk that the proposed FOs could be dominated by feudal landlords, and thereby ineffective. Finally, there is a risk of legal impediments that prevent the FOs from taking over management responsibilities for the tertiary system. The loss in terms of equity, cost recovery, and ensuring accountability would be significant, and their impacts on O&M of the system (through losses on service quality and cost :recovery) would also be significant. In addition, slow formation of FOs would also disrupt the strategy to improve O&M of the tertiary system by transferring responsibility to user groups. This would directly affect the fiscal savings expected to be achieved through the project (estimated to be about Rs. 2.5 billion or US$62 million at completion). 5.18 Risk-mitigation and Risk-management: The risk-mitigation factors are detailed below: (i) the most important factor mitigating this risk is the expected encouragement from positive results of on-going pilots of FOs. These pilots would also help to reduce the perceived threats to the i nterests of the opponents of reforms in the sector. The early results from these pilot projects indicate that FOs are socially viable i.e., with appropriate social engineering techniques, it is possible to form user groups in the prevailing socio- cultural and political environment. The pilots have also identified a need for these user groups to be empowered and authorized to carry out economic activities i.e., to manage the tertiary level system57. The project's farmer participation plan includes a special effort to replicate lessons from current pilots, and to implement early action plans to build FOs; (ii) the selection criteria for Investment Projects provides an in- built incentive for formnation of FOs (since the selection criteria specifies that on-farm drainage and irrigation upto the minor/ distributary level would be carried out by FOs); (iii) the project's social mobilization activities and awareness initiatives, the front-end cost-sharing arrangements for investments (which would necessarily require consultation with beneficiaries), and assistance to the private sector for providing contracting services for on-farm subsurface drainage facilities, would facilitate formation of FOs; and (iv) the PIDA Acts clearly define the roles and responsibilities of FOs which include the management of the tertiary system. The risk management strategy is the same as that indicated in para 5.16 above. 5.19 Quantitative Assessment of Political-Economy Risk: A quantitative risk assessment of the major institutional reforms was conducted58. This consisted of: (i) an evaluation of the potential winners and losers from the reforms; (ii) identification of the various reform performance levels; (iii) identification of means by which the various parties could influence the level of achievement of various reforms; and (iv) identification of costs to (i.e., effort required by) each party to influence the achievement levels; and thereafter using the Delphi approach to estimate probabilities of level of achievement of each reform. This analysis indicated that the reform performance levels are likely to vary across reforms. The most likely scenario is a medium level of (partial) achievement on reforms relating to: (i) institutional reforms in PIDs; (ii) transfer of management responsibilities of the tertiary system to FOs; (iii) redefining the operational jurisdictions of various PAs; and (iv) carrying out O&M through Performance Contracts awarded to the private sector; and a low level of achievement on establishment of water rights. 57 These lessons are drawn from the pilot project for farmer-managed irrigated agriculture under the LBOD Project with technical assistance from IIMI (Moving Towards Participatory Irrigation Management - Phase II Report, January 1997, IIMI). 58 Institutional Reforms in the Water Sector in Pakistan - Political Economy and Political Risk, Working Paper for the National Drainage Program, May 1997.
 43 5.20 Sustainability of Investments in Irrigation and Drainage Infrastructure: Experience has demonstrated that the key requirement for sustainability of irrigation and drainage projects in Pakistan is a steady-state post-completion O&M regime, with a reliable source of funding. As indicated earlier, the proposed policy and institutional reforms are the most significant assurance for sustainability of investments. There is however a risk that given that the institutional reforns may take many years to be fully effective, the gains of the investments made in the interim period may not be sustainable, if real institutional reform does not take place. To mitigate this risk, the project's design provides for institutional reforms to precede investments in irrigation and drainage infrastructure. Each Investment Project (designed on a basin or sub-basin approach with a proper outfall) would virtually be a 'stand-alone' investment. A reduction in the overall level of investments would not affect the economic viability of the entire project. A related issue for sustainability of the system is a long-term solution for disposal of drainage effluent outside the Indus Basin. The project would support the preparation of feasibility studies and detailed design for the Borrower's proposed NSDS which is intended to create a permanent disposal channel for drainage effluent via the LBOD into the Arabian Sea. 5.21 Implementation Delays: The other main risk to the project during its implementation phase is slow implementation due to factors such as poor coordination, weak supervision, delays in preparation of Investrnent Projects, delays in approval of contracts and investment projects, and failure of PAs to meet eligibility criteria on schedule. To reduce these risks, authority and responsibility have been decentralized significantly to PAs. The project is embedded in broad-based capacity building efforts for WAPDA, PIDAs, AWBs, FOs, and PAD-OFWMs; and its design provides for extensive supervision and implementation assistance. Finally, there are built-in mechanisms to ensure that there is a high degree of client participation in the formulation and implementation of all the studies and research contracts. To reduce the risks of delay, the contract with the NDP Engineering Design and Supervision Consultants (who would assist substantially in the preparation of Investment Projects) has been signed. Contracts for civil works which would be carried out in the first year have been signed or are in an advanced stage (post bid- evaluation) of procurement processing. Several research contracts are also in an advanced stage of procurement processing and are expected to be signed before Effectiveness. 5.22 Sensitivity Analysis for Investment Projects: The illustrative economic analysis carried out for a sample of the project's interventions demonstrated that the economic viability of the Investment Projects is fairly robust. Sensitivity analyses were undertaken to determine the effects on economic viability of: (i) delays in project benefits resulting from slow implementation; (ii) increases in project costs resulting from inefficient management and other factors; (iii) lower than predicted yields for major crops; and (iv) lower prices for major commodity outputs; and (v) a shorter duration of project benefits. The analysis indicated that the economic viability would be affected only with large adverse changes in these variables. D. At the Investment Project formulation stage, priority would ideally be given to drainage requiring drainage with the following characteristics:
 51 ANNEX 1 Page 5 of 9 (a) located in highly developed irrigated zones with potentially high "gross margins," i.e., zones with high cropping intensity, high yields, and cash crops; and (b) where over a 3-5 year period, the yields have been static or decreasing, the total cropped area is falling, and farmers are shifting to cropping patterns that have lower returns. 9. At the formulation stage, every effort would ideally be made to exclude any Investment Projects: (a) that do not have effective outfall to the main drainage system; (b) that require reclamation of highly sodic soils; (c) in abandoned areas, especially when cropping intensity in other areas not as severely affected can be increased and irrigation water is scarce; (d) where salts would be mobilized from groundwater without adequate drainage outlet for safe disposal; (e) that would have serious environmental impacts or problems which cannot easily be mitigated by measures included within the project definition; and (f) that do not have a plan and budget for an awareness campaign concerning the benefits of drainage and improved water management directed at beneficiaries. 10. Guidelines for Screening at Feasibility Stage: In a situation where the number of candidate Investment Projects is too large to allow all of them to be taken forward to the feasibility analysis stage, the following criteria would be used for prioritizing Investment Project candidates: (a) Main off-farm drains: Only those that have lost at least 30 percent of their carrying capacity would be included. Priority would normally be given based on the following criteria in descending order: (i) where farmers are willing to rehabilitate subdrains on self-help basis and undertake subsequent O&M; (ii) waterlogged area in a highly developed irrigated zone; (iii) stormwater drains in cotton-wheat zone; and (iv) other irrigated areas. (b) On-farm drains: All existing and new tributary drains with outfalls discharge less than 15 cusecs would be given priority if they are to be rehabilitated or constructed under a community tertiary drainage scheme or private tile drainage scheme. In this subcategory, priority would ideally be given to (in descending order): (i) those Investment Projects with existing environmentally acceptable outfalls; (ii) areas underlain by saline groundwater (SGW) (for subsurface drainage); and (iii) Fresh groundwater (FGW) areas with poor aquifer. (c) Drainage tubewells (SGW): Reduction in discharge and specific capacity should ideally be taken into account. SGW tubewell replacement and rehabilitation would only be considered if tile drainage is not technically feasible; and if there is an environmental acceptable disposal arrangement. 11. Economic Analysis: All Investment Projects that pass feasibility stage would be subject to a detailed economic analysis before consideration for funding under NDP. The analysis would closely follow the Planning Commission's revised Guidelines dated October 1995 for preparing projects in the water sector (which include social, environmental, hand-over, land acquisition and resettlement, and post-completion O&M aspects). To be considered for funding under NDP, an Investment Project should have an economic rate of return (ERR) of at least 15%3 and a positive benefit/investment ratio. 3 The Opportunity Cost of Capital in Pakistan is estimated to lie somewhere between 12-15 %.

In particular Cost Tables, Indus Basin Model Revised (IBMR)4, and the geographical information system would be used to check the validity and consistency of cost and benefit estimates, descriptions of the project area and affected lands, and identification and assessment of environmental impacts. The Plan Generator component of the NDP Informaticn System would also be used to simulate an objective comparison of the worth of altermative Investment Projects to derive plans which are optimal within the assumed budgetary constraints. 14. Least-Cost Slice-and-Package Investment Projects: To ease the administrative burden and expedite approval, Investment Projects whose costs are estimated by the sponsors and confirmed by the NDP Coordination Cell or Provincial NDP Cell to cost below $10 million would be implemented on the basis of least-cost slice-and- package procedures under which standard costs and other uniformly applicable criteria would be applied to the evaluation, financing, and implementation of the Investment Projects. Such procedures would be developed for all categories of Investment Projects, but are expected to be applied most frequently for on-farm drainage; lining of watercourses in SGW areas; transition of FGW tubewells; transfer, rehabilitation or construction of subdrains; installation of standard measurement, gauging and control equipment; O&M Performance Contracts; repetitive consultancy packages for identical services or clients; repetitive equipment and machinery for identical clients or purposes; training; and for eligible procurement and expenditures of AWBs, FOs, NGOs, WUAs, DBGs, and community organizations. The NDP Coordination Cell, working in coordination with Provincial NDP Cells, wou].d submit and agree with IDA annually: (i) the package of Investment Projects; and (ii) standard guidelines and unit rates for implementation of projects under the Least-Cost Slice-and-Package approach. 4 To support the economic analysis, IBMR would be used in a revised form to simulate the direct and indirect impacts of the investment project on the cropping pattem, resource use, farmers' income, and labor requirements vis-a-vis changes in salinity and watertable. The revised version of IBMR would include upgrading and validation of the IBMR at the micro (project) level to represent the impacts of individual investment projects within an agro-climatic zone, including more accurate agricultural production data, yield-salinity and yield-watertable coefficients, and land use and cropping decisions. The model would also be further refined to model lateral flows and evaporation.

 63 ANNEX3 Page I of 7 PARTICIPATION AGREEMENT ASPECTS TO BE COVERED IN PARTICIPATION AGREEMENTS 1. Introduction: This Annex sets out the aspects which would be covered in Participation Agreements between Provinces and PIDAs, AWBs and FOs participating in the Project. The Participation Agreements would be between the concemed Province and the PIDA, AWB or FO to which funds from the Project are being provided by the Province concerned. A separate Participation Agreement would be signed with each PIDA, AWB or FO. Legal Counsel financed under the Project, or NDP Consultants would provide assistance required by the Provinces, PIDAs, AWBs, or FOs in preparing and negotiating the Participation Agreement on request by the Province/PIDA, AWB or FO. 2. Effectiveness: The Participation Agreement would become effective upon the date of its signature or on the Effective Date of the Development Credit Agreement and Project Agreement for NDP, whichever is later. 3. Compliance with Other Agreements: The PIDA, AWB or FO concerned would comply with the provisions of all relevant sections of the Development Credit Agreement and Project Agreement for the project signed with IDA, and with similar agreements with ADB and OECF for the project. 4. Eligibility for Incremental Financing Commitments: The PIDA, AWB or FO concerned shall furnish with respect to each Fiscal Year of Project implementation, evidence to IDA, showing that they are, and shall continue during such Fiscal Year to be, in compliance with the eligibility criteria set forth in Schedule 1 to the Project Agreement (these eligibility criteria are outlined in Annex 6 of the SAR). The PIDA, AWB or FO would be eligible for incremental financing commitments from the IDA Credit for new programs of activities to be commenced under the Project, and any new contracts to be awarded by it for on-going Investment Projects only after it has furnished this evidence. 5. Organization and Functions: The PIDA, AWBs or FO would: (i) maintain organizational structure, functions, staffing, and regulatory framework, all satisfactory to IDA, for the period of project implementation and post-completion monitoring; and (ii) promptly inform IDA of any proposed change in the organizational structures, functions, staffing, or regulatory framework. 6. Autonomy, Accountability, and Efficiency: The PIDA, AWB or FO concerned would be: (i) established and run as an autonomous entity; (ii) established and run in accordance with generally accepted business practice, under which Owners (whether Provinces or farmers), Board of Directors, and Management would be completely separate; and (iii) audited by Chartered Accountants appointed in consultation with IDA. 7. Recruitment of Managing Directors and Senior Officers of PIDAs, AWBs and FOs: The PIDA or AWB concerned would recruit Managing Directors and Senior Officers from PIDs and/or the market through transparent processes (i.e., including by advertising in the press, and the use of specialized professional management recruitment firms). Managing Directors and Senior Officers would be acceptable to IDA. 8. Staffing Levels: The PIDA or AWB concerned would prepare and implement a "Staffng, Operational and Financial Plan"; impose a hiring freeze; reassign staff; and encourage voluntary retirement until it achieves the desired staffing levels. 9. Regulatory and Corporate Oversight: The PIDA concerned would: (i) establish a Policy & Regulation Wing; and (ii) assign responsibility for establishing policy and regulating the operations of entities to the Wing.
 64 ANNEX 3 Page 2 of 7 10. Legal Cell: The PIDA concerned would establish a Legal Cell with Tenns of Reference and staff, including Chief Legal Counsel/Officer, agreed with IDA, to advise on regulatory and legal matters relating to the decentralized irrigation and drainage system. Operations 11. Management Transfer: The management of the irrigation and drainage system in the operating jurisdiction of the PIDA, AWB or FO concerned would be legally transferred to it through leases or other contractually enforceable mechanism which shall have been established by the Province in consultation with IDA. The operating jurisdiction of the PIDA, AWB or FO would be as given below: (a) FO: (i) on-farm drainage; and (ii) on-farn irrigation upto minor/distributary level; (b) AWB: intra-provincial irrigation and drainage within its canal command (other than on- farm drainage and irrigation); and (c) PIDA: (i) intra-provincial irrigation and drainage outside canal commands; and (ii) intra- provincial irrigation and drainage within canal commands in which AWBs have not been established (other than on-farm drainage and irrigation). This would be an interim arrangement until AWBs have been established in all canal comamands. 12. Service Standards: The PIDA, AWB or FO concerned would adhere to a clear set of service standards which shall have been agreed with its clients, and which shall be monitorable and contractually enforceable. 13. Streamlining and Cost Reduction in Operations of Decentralized Irrigation Institutions: The PIDA, AWB, or FO concerned would implement measures aimed at reducing O&M costs, and thereby reduce the cost recovery base including: (a) formulating new service regulations and personnel policies; (b) streamlining machine operations; (c) updating and revising service and technical manuals; (d) improving accounting and financial management systems; (e) conducting specific diagnostic analyses and implementing subsequent action plans to streamline operations of selected drainage circles; (f) streamlining fmancing and utilization of the O&M budget - inter alia by linking O&M financing with collection of Abiana (the financing aspect of streamlining) and increasing the share of works in the budget (the utilization aspect of streamlining) in selected pilot areas; (g) streamlining implementation of off-farm drainage O&M through Performance Contracts (PCs) or Rehabilitate and Operate Contracts (ROCs) or other scheme awarded to the private sector on competitive basis, and designating Drainage Circles for PCs; (h) initiating pilots to test decentralization of Abiana assessment and collection during implementation of NDP, and designating Circles where pilots to test decentralization of Abiana assessment and implementation would be implemented; (i) rationalizing "Abiana" schedule; (j) building their capacities for delivery of services under the new framework; (k) transferring on-farm drains and tertiary drains to FOs and WUAs; and (I) transitioning as many FGW tubewells as possible. 14. Delivery and Pricing for Wholesale Irrigation and Drainage Services: The PIDA, AWB, or FO concerned would design, test/pilot, and if successful, implement a system of demand, delivery, and payment of wholesale irrigation and drainage services all based on advance planning prior to the agricultural seasons. Under such a system, PIDAs would eventually deliver services to AWBs based on the aggregate demand from them, while AWBs would do likewise based on aggregate demand from FOs, who would base theirs on the demand from WUAs. Payment would be determined through negotiations at these aggregate levels as well; and losses (arising from operational inefficiencies arising from mismanagement and/or overstaffing, non-recovery of charges, leakages due to corruption, or system losses due to excessive seepage or poor maintenance) would be absorbed by the responsible parties, and not transmitted system- wide. PIDAs would have the power to set water charges to AWBs only; aind would sell wholesale irrigation and drainage services to them on a full cost-recovery basis. PIDAs' receivables from individual AWBs would be independent of AWBs' receipts from FOs; and losses would not be transferred from one
 65 ANNEX 3 Page 3 of 7 AWB to another. PIDAs would compensate AWBs for services for which AWBs are not expected to recover costs; or which they carry out at the behest or direction of PIDAs. AWBs would similarly set wholesale charges and deliver services to, and obtain payment from, individual FOs; and FOs would do so likewise with WUAs. 15. Procurement Assessment: The Borrower and IDA have carried out a "Country Procurement Assessment for Pakistan" in 1995; and the Report is expected to be published soon. The NDP Procurement Unit: WAPDA would establish an NDP Procurement Unit with terms of reference, staffing from WAPDA and procurement consultants, and budgets satisfactory to IDA. WAPDA would appoint one or more consultants with internationally recognized professional qualifications in procurement administration, from NDP Engineering Design and Supervision Consultants or other consultants, as NDP Procurement Advisers to provide technical assistance and training to staff of WAPDA, PIDAs, AWBs, and FOs on procurement. An NDP Procurement Manager (PM) will head the NDP Procurement Unit which will be established by the NDP Cell. The PM will be the Deputy Chief Resident Engineer (Contracts) of the NDP Engineering Design and Supervision Consultants. (iv) to formulate and implement policies with a view to achieve and continuously improve effective, economical and efficient utilization of irrigation water at its disposal on a financially and environmentally sustainable basis; (v) to operate and maintain the irrigation and drainage, storage reservoirs and flood control infrastructure located within its territorial jurisdiction and to plan, design, construct and/or improve the same to ensure supply of irrigation water to water users within its jurisdiction and conveyance and/or disposal of drainage effluent on reasonable and efficient basis; (vi) to execute, implement and maintain, after prior written agreement as to the relevant terms and conditions and the extent and mode of payment for the same, such scheme(s) as may be entrusted to it by the PIDA or by any agency or entity of the Government; (viii) to formulate and implement policies with a view to ensuring that within a period not exceeding ten years from the date of its constitution it becomes fully operative as a self supporting and financially self sustaining entity for O&M costs;  96 ANNEX 9 Page I of 18 ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 1. Introduction: The framework for economic analysis links the project's interventions (institutional reforms, institutional, research and sector planning, and drainage investments) to anticipated impacts and benefits. The analysis establishes linkages between the project and country and sector strategies and includes quantitative and qualitative analyses of fiscal impacts, portfolio management, poverty, environmental impacts, institutional analysis, and Investment Projects. A. SECTOR ANALYSIS AND RATIONALE FOR PUBLIC SECTOR ROLE 2. Sectoral Analysis/Reviews: Research and IDA experience suggests that next to sound economic policy framework, the basis for sound investment decisions and implementation performance is a sound sectoral analysis, particularly public expenditure reviews (PERs). The project is based on a number of sectoral analyses, three of which are most important: (i) the Borrower's Water Sector Investment Planning Study (WSIPS, 1993); (ii) the Borrower's Drainage Sector Environmental Assessment (DSEA, 1993); and (iii) the Bank's Irrigation and Drainage Issues and Options paper (1994). 3. Public Expenditure Reviews: IDA, jointly with ADB and OECF has conducted an Annual Review of the Public Sector Development Program (PSDP) since 1992. IDA has conducted an Annual Country Poryfolio Performance Review (CPPR) with the Borrower, WAPDA, and Provinces since 1992. The water sector has featured prominently in the annual reviews of the PSDP and CPPRs. The Feasibility Study for the project included a detailed review of the Public Expenditure Program for Drainage. The results of the Bank's study of "Fiscal Decentralization in Pakistan" were incorporated in the design of the project during Appraisal. By recalculating the ERRs of projects which were originally contained in the PSDPs of the Borrower and Provinces, the NDP Feasibility Study Consultants were able to recommend a different mix of projects in the PSDPs, saving the Government millions of dollars from the combined PSDP of the Borrower and Provinces. It is expected that the project will provide the basis, mechanism, and resources around which the continuous evaluation of the PSDP for irrigation and drainage would be evaluated annually, and high priority public sector investments financed. 4. Private Sector Counterfactual: The public expenditure programs which would be financed under the project have been identified after several rigorous reviews of the aspects of drainage and irrigation capital and recurrent expenditures which the private sector can or should provide. The reviews and sector analysis cited above concluded that the private sector should be responsible for substantial investment costs, and almost all recurrent costs of on-farm drainage, lining of watercourses in SGW areas, FGW tubewells, and tertiary drainage (subdrains). Off-farm drainage, however, is largely a public good and regarded to be within the public sector domain, because the costs of inadequate drainage, costs of providing remedy in the form of drainage relief, and benefits of drainage are borne largely by the public (though mostly the farming community) at large. The cost recovery and sharing proposals also take into account incidence of public investment and private or public gains. The project is designed to make the transition to the public-private roles described above. 5. The Policy Environment: Economic theory indicates that rates of return to investments such as the project would be higher if they are implemented in a policy environment which has fewer distortions. Pakistan has implemented many policy reforms in the past decade which have helped to improve the policy environment for successful implementation of irrigation and drainage projects. 6. Water Rights: Water rights exist in Pakistan on an informal basis. There is a growing concern in Pakistan about increased and inefficient allocation and use of water resources. Attention is therefore being focused on the use of water rights in water allocation. Water rights (through price signals) could better allocate water and provide incentives for more efficient water use in agriculture, industry, and urban areas. Tradable water-use rights that are separate from land may be established. Past use of water could be a basis for allocation. Once established, water rights can be officially registered. Since a major objective of
 97 ANNEX 9 Page 2 of 18 NDP is to reduce the drainable surplus inter alia through improving efficiency in water use and improving canal delivery systems, a study of water rights would be inplemented under the project. 7. Experience of countries such as Chile that have encouraged and practiced water markets in water management has important implications for countries facing water scarcity and are considering introducing water markets: there are significant gains from trade which can realized by fostering water markets; transferable water-use rights or water rights, separate from land, are essential for water markets (these rights can be stipulated by volume or by percentage of river or canal flow); great care should be exercised in the initial allocation of water-use rights among users in order to make sure that most of the rights are not captured by a few individuals; technology, such as adjustable gates, and institutional arrangements that encourage the formation of active water users' associations can substantially redluce transaction costs and facilitate market trading; the presence of privately held water rights does not necessarily make it more difficult to reach environmental water quality objectives (water quality regulations need to be established and enforced irrespective of the water allocation system); within a decentralized system of water resource management, there is a continuing role for water management authorities in enforcing water rights and resolving conflicts; and where irrigation systems have been built with public funds, there is an important question concerning how much, if any, of the economic surplus generated by water trades should governments try to capture. For a country like Pakistan with long rivers and extensive return flows, the issue of water rights for users of return flows would have to be addressed in their water code. B. EXPECTED BENEFITS 8. Introduction: The project is an integral part of Pakistan's National Drainage Program (NDP), which is anchored within the country's medium-term public expenditure plan. It focuses on the core priority drainage investments. Its principal short term benefits will come from improvements in the physical drainage and more effective operating drainage, which would leadl to increased output of agricultural produce. It would also have a direct and positive impact on drained farm lands, regardless of the socioeconomic characteristics of farmers cultivating these lands. It is estimated that farmers benefiting from the drainage improvements can expect an increase in their net farm income of up to 30 percent, depending on the local drainage and the agro-ecological conditions. 9. The principal medium- and long-term benefits will be improved drainage and irrigation- related policies, improved efficiency of public expenditures on drainage O&M, iimproved capability in the public sector to plan and implement water sector projects and in the private sector to undertake drainage- related investments, all of which will benefit the environment and the agricultural sector as a whole. These benefits will potentially be far greater than those from the physical drainage investments. Fiscal Impacts 10. The project's fiscal impacts will be reflected in the capital and recurTent budgets at both the Federal and Provincial levels. The project is also expected to have an impact on investment portfolio management. These impacts are discussed below. II. Development Budget Impacts: Analysis was conducted to address the issue of fiscal impact of the project, in part because concern has been expressed regarding the project's size. Given the fungibility of money, IDA could in effect be financing, at the margin, a different project than the one appraised. Accordingly, it was also important to be satisfied that the sectoral and overall investment program was appropriate. The fiscal analysis draws on results of recent public expenditure reviews. 12. The Borrower's efforts to reduce its fiscal deficit has resulted in a progressively tightening squeeze on the PSDP. At the same time, improving disbursement performance and higher lending by some of the major donors imply rising budgetary requirements to provide for the needs of foreign assistance program. There is an emerging inconsistency between the tightening budget and the growing foreign assistance program. Adverse effects of this inconsistency are likely to be maniiested in under-budgeting
 98 ANNEX 9 Page 3 of 18 the requirements of donor assisted projects and programs; and a tendency for the foreign aided component of the PSDP to exceed the budget target (since some disbursements are independent of counterpart funds or budget restrictions), weakening fiscal programming. 13. Macroeconomic Impact (Relation to the Economy): An assessment of the macroeconomic sustainability of the proposed project was done by comparing key macroeconomic indicators on a set of macroeconomic projections with and without NDP, using data on GDP, PSDP, investment costs, and the financing plan for the project. A somewhat slower pace of macroeconomic and structural reforms (but no backtracking) as assumed in the Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) for Pakistan, is used as the macroeconomic framework for the NDP. Portfolio Management: Drainage projects in Pakistan have typically been inadequately prepared, programmed, implemented, and not well integrated with Five Year or the Annual Development Programs (ADP). Moreover, the selection of projects has not always been rational or transparent. Allocation of development funds is on the basis of fixed provincial shares and not according to drainage needs. The result is that the portfolio of drainage projects is characterized by implementation delays, too many incomplete projects, inadequate financing (especially of counterpart funds), poor quality of construction, low rates of return at entry, and cost overruns. The Feasibility Study for the project showed that the "throwforward," a term used by the Planning Commission to describe the value of projects which are carried from one Five Year or Annual Development Plan into the next, from the Seventh Five Year Plan (1989-93) into the Eighth Five Year Plan (1993-98) rose to a record of Rs. 54.7 billion. Poverty Impacts 28. Positive Poverty Impacts: Areas which are affected by high levels of waterlogging and salinity tend to have the lowest incomes, high unemployment, and lawlessness in Pakistan. Hence these problems have a poverty and equity dimension too. They affect the rural poor (especially those at tail-ends of watercourses and minors) and landless tenants most severely. The project would sassist in poverty reduction by increasing agricultural output (food and cash crops). Since agriculture is among the most effective tools

The selection criteria for Investment Projects are designed to skew the benefits in favor of tenant farmers, smallholders, and tail-enders. Specifically, Investment Projects would, to the extent possible, be designed to benefit small farmers, women, and poorest one-third of the income strata of the members of the farming community. This would be demonstrated through a Social Assessment for the Investment Project. The institutional reforms, particularly the formation of FOs, are expected to increase the transparency and equity of water allocation and use. The poor would also benefit from flood protection provided by the project. 29. The project is designed to facilitate reduction and evacuation of the drainable surplus so as to increase agricultural production that is broadly based and provide appropriate spillover effects on non-farm growth through backward and forward linkages. Thus, the project would address the multifaceted problem of poverty alleviation by increasing employment opportunities in the non-farm sector and increasing productivity of marginal farmers and landless tenants. For every I percent increase in per capita farm growth, it is estimated that the project would provide a 1.5 percent increase in per capita non-farm growth in the year 200 1'. 30. Income Distribution Impacts: While the project's water management investmnents would improve water resource allocation efficiencies between owners of land at the head and tail of canals, it is likely that agricultural production benefits would still be skewed towards large land owners. However, benefits to large land owners would likely encourage domestic resource mobilization in rural areas, which would lead to benefits to the poor in terms of additional farm and non-farm employment opportunities. There is a reasonable probability that the drainage investments would benefit the rural elite and landlords to a greater extent than the rural poor, thus exacerbating rural income inequality. To address this risk, Investment Project selection criteria would favor areas and beneficiaries who are in the bottom one-third income strata of the farming community. In addition, the requirement that beneficiaries contribute to the cost of installing drains in their areas through labor would likely select-out the rural elite. However, the rural elite may simply hire day laborers to do the job. The project's actual and potential impacts on rural income, poverty, and income distribution would be monitored closely during the first phase of implementation, and necessary adjustments would be made, based on the results of the MTR. Historical benefits from drainage research by IWASRI (one of the PRIs) in Pakistan illustrate the up-side potential benefits which can be expected from the proposed drainage research subcomponent. The benefits of improved drainage design can be gleaned from the Fourth Drainage Project. During the design and construction of the Fourth Drainage Project, important reductions in cost, compared with first designs, were realized as a result of integrating the findings of concurrent research which was undertaken on one of the project sites (sump). The length of subsurface drains was reduced from 1,600 miles to 500 miles, and the number of sumps from 250 to 79; with a reduction in project nominal costs from Rs. 700 million to Rs. 300 million despite the effects of inflation associated with an implementation period of 11 years. Application of groundwater models to drainage design enabled the identification of spatially varying drainage needs, which led to the abandonment of the uniform spacing of subsurface drains that had previously been planned/assumed for the design of the component. 35. The benefits of research on design criteria for drainage can be inferred from the recent work of IWASRI; which shows that the drainage coefficient for tile drainage projects which were designed before 1990 was overly conservative; and has therefore been reduced in more recent projects. The reduction in the drainage coefficient has not only greatly reduced the capital cost of drainage projects, but also the recurrent costs and the quantity of drainage effluent for disposal, thereby reducing the adverse environmental impact associated with disposal requirements of drainage effluent on the downstream users, and other effects of tile drainage. As a result of these research findings, the drainage coefficient has been reduced from 2.7 mm/d under Fordwah Eastern Sadiqia (in 1990), to 1.8 mm/d in planning for Khushab SCARP; and the drainage coefficient for Fordwah Eastern Sadiqia has recently been reduced to 1.5 mm/d
 105 ANNEX 9 Page 10 of 18 following the discussions which emanated from IWASRI's research. This shows that designers of drainage projects in Pakistan have now gained confidence that a design with a lower drainage coefficient can concurrently meet the objectives of watertable control, reducing project caipital and recurrent costs substantially. The proposed subcomponent on drainage research under the project will support further research to better determine the drainage coefficient. 36. The benefits of Pakistan's recent research on interceptor drains are equally significant. Seepage from canals is one of the major contributors to waterlogging. Interceptor drains to recover this seepage have been constructed at a few sites in Pakistan; and were planned for Fordwah Eastern Sadiqia (South) Project, and under LBOD. The estimated cost of interceptor drains in Fordwah Eastern Sadiqia (South) is Rs. 500 million; while the cost in LBOD is Rs. 768 million. Research fndings from IWASRI after these projects had been approved indicated that interceptors should be used selectively, and not as a standard technique for recovering seepage from canals, because the effectiveness of the interceptors was too low (30%, which implied that to recover 0.5 cusec net, 2.7 cusec has to be pumped); and would lead to excessive O&M costs. 37. Drainage research has also contributed to the reduction of costs for drain envelopes. In Pakistan, gravel is traditionally used as drain envelope; whereas there is a worldwide trend to use synthetic materials. IWASRI has started laboratory and field tests to establish applicability of synthetic materials as drain envelope. Test lines have been laid in Fourth Drainage Project, and are scheduled for Fordwah Eastern Sadiqia Project. Switching from gravel to synthetic envelopes has already resulted in capital cost savings as high as 40% in the Fourth Drainage Project with the same level of drainage collection and efficiency. 38. For the purpose of assessing the economic rate of return of the project, the direct quantifiable benefits from rehabilitation and improvement of the public sector surface drains and construction of on-farm drainage works would be considered. These interventions will improve drainage conditions, resulting in higher crop yields and cropping intensity. 45. Production Benefits: The proposed project would have two important impacts. Drainage installation would lower the groundwater table and reduce soil salinity, thereby leading to rapidly improved yields and lower production cost. The project also addresses a long-term issue: vvithout the project, future yields would progressively decline from their current levels. The project would have two additional benefits: (a) the avoidance of further yield (production) losses, which would result if the groundwater and salinity problems were to persist; and (b) the productivity increase resulting from reducing waterlogging/salinity problems. The "without" project situation would lead to a substantial loss in agricultural production and an environmental disaster and great suffering for farmers. The rising of the deep saline watertable would reduce yields to almost zero once it reaches the crop root zone. Large areas of crop land would completely go out of production in the "without" project scenario. Productivity increase is the most imnportant of the two benefit subsets. The sum of the benefits represents the "with and without" project situation, rather than the "before and after" situation. Insofar as improved drainage may have positive effects on agricultural technologies or cultural practices, the benefits are understated. 46. The project is expected to benefit many farmers directly, and the entire irrigated sector indirectly, by reclaiming abandoned land, rehabilitating existing lands, and improving drainage in about 13.5 million acres. Agricultural benefits would come from increased crop production and employment as a result of reduction in watertable depth and soil salinity, and better operations and maintenance of irrigation system through private sector involvement and improved performance of public institutions in the water sector as a result of institutional strengthening. Cropped area, cropping intensity, and crop yields are expected to increase as a result of the project. Cropping patterns are also expected to change due to reduced soil salinity, waterlogging, and flooding. Crops that are less tolerant to salinity and waterlogging can be grown in the "with project" situation. Production would increase over the "without project" situation due to both (i) the direct effects of decreased saline intrusions and (ii) improved drainage. The annual incremental production expected from the project's investment component is summarized below. 47. Additional benefits would accrue from new investments which have been identified but not prepared or appraised, and some which have not yet been identified. The benefits of new investments are assumed to mirror but be higher than those for rehabilitation and modernization (see para below), although the benefit- cost ratio would be more favorable for rehabilitation and remodeling. 48. Rehabilitation & Modernization of Off-Farm Drainage: A number of surface drains are proposed for rehabilitation and remodeling. Projections for agricultural production without surface drain investments in the selected areas are that yields would gradually decrease and over a thirty year period be reduced by 50 percent. Costs of production would gradually increase as planting and sowing, harvesting, and fertilizer continue to grow as a percentage of production inputs. Surface drains are expected to reduce the number of days the land is waterlogged and decrease salinity and thus reclaim cultivable command area, improve planting and harvesting efficiency, and decrease costs of production including planting and sowing, harvesting and fertilizer. 49. Rehabilitation & Modernization of Water Management: The component is expected to provide canal commands with improved telecommunications and equipment. Rehabilitation of the canal commands is expected to improve water carrying capacity of drains and reduce crop losses from flooding. It will also significantly increase water deliveries to tail-end farmers. Modernizing canal commands with improved telecommunications and equipment would have a positive impact on the distribution of water and provide for better water control. Improved distribution of water will affect agricultural production in the entire cultivable command area and improve productivity. The intervention would also increase productivity and decrease maintenance costs of production for tail-end farmers, who will now receive a steady and reliable source of water. Agricultural productivity is expected to start increasing from the year after completion of construction works. It is estimated that productivity would improve by 2 percent for the entire command area and by an additional 20 percent for tail-end farmers. Tail-end farmers would also realize additional benefits from a 1.5 percent reduction in costs of production. Productivity and costs are expected to remain steady in future years after the initial impact. It is estimated that rehabilitation would increase productivity and cropping intensities by 2 percent as a result of reduced crop damage from breaches in canals and flooding, and an additional 5 percent for tail-end farmers, who would observe a significant increase in surface water deliveries. 50. Lining Watercourses in Saline Groundwater Areas: The primary objective of lining watercourses is to increase agricultural production through effective use of irrigation water saved by renovation of watercourses and application of improved on-farm water management practices. It is expected, for example, that 750 watercourses would be lined in saline groundwater (SGW) areas around Nara Canal Command and Khairpur East; the projections for agricultural production without lining watercourses in saline areas of Nara and Khairpur in the Sanghar and Khairpur Districts are that yields would remain constant and cost of production would increase gradually due to rising costs of planting, harvesting, etc. It is estimated that lining watercourses would have a positive impact on the distribution of water at the watercourse level and would affect agricultural production by 11 percent in Sanghar and Khairpur. It is also anticipated that the intervention would provide for saving water conveyance losses by 5% and 10% in lined and unlined watercourses, respectively. Benefits on agricultural productivity are expected to occur immediately the year after construction. Productivity and costs are expected to remain steady in future years after the initial impact. 51. Potential Production Losses: The investment component of the project is expected to lead to some loss in agricultural production since some agricultural land will be acquired for project purposes. The NDP Feasibility Study Consultants estimated that about 1.21 hectares of land will be acquired for each kilometer of off-farm surface drains rehabilitated or built. On that basis, it is estimated that a total of 8,696 hectares of land are likely to be acquired. Current average net income in the project areas is estimated at

This loss would be more than offset by expected benefits. Estimation Of Economic Rates Of Return And Net Present Values 52. The selection criteria requires that Investment Projects should have a minimum economic rate of return (ERR), excluding non-quantifiable benefits, of 15 percent. The various types of Investment Projects which would be supported under the project have had historically high ERRs (200/%-50%) in Pakistan'0. Studies of completed projects in Pakistan also show that higher ERRs are achieved under program rather than project approach for the same type of investments. Drainage projects in other countries also show high rates of return". The economic analysis for the potential Investment Projects in the pipeline (given in the Table below) indicate that substantial number of these projects, covering various types of interventions, would meet the ERR selection criteria. The ERRs of the various types of Investrment Projects also span a wide range. These reflect variations in cropping patterns and yield levels, the degree of surface flooding and its frequency, the extent of waterlogging, and the available irrigation supplies. doc.abstracts: The objectives of the National Drainage Program Project are to improve the efficiency of the irrigation and drainage system in Pakistan, and ensure its sustainability. The project is designed as a sector investment project, consisting of three complementary components: 1) a sector planning and research component facilitating long-term sector and project planning, namely, for the National Surface Drainage System (NSDS) to carry saline effluent from the drainage network to the sea, and enhancing the technical foundations of drainage; 2) the institutional reforms component, the most important component, aimed at decentralizing provincial irrigation departments, and streamlining and building the capacity of water and power development authorities, provincial irrigation and drainage authorities, area water boards, on-farm water management directorates of provincial agricultural departments, and farmers' organizations; and 3) the investment component, designed to improve drainage and water management infrastructure, and to protect inland wetlands, which finances completion of ongoing projects, rehabilitation and remodeling of completed drainage projects, and new projects which conform to or support the overall strategies of the project.
